TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that at the placing of business I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, notices of motion Nos 1, 2, 3 and 4 standing in my name for this day, for disallowance of certain Customs regulations, an environment protection order, Australian citizenship regulations and certain Public Service regulations. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1987, Senator Stone on my behalf told the Senate that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was examining certain delegated legislation with reference to our bipartisan scrutiny principles. Protective notices of motion of disallowance were given on that date to protect the Committee's position while Ministers considered the Committee's queries. That process has now concluded on this the last day on which it could conclude. The Committee's concerns about the legislation have been allayed by ministerial undertakings to amend instruments, as well as by some convincing explanations of the background to certain matters. I emphasise that the Committee will be following up with the relevant Ministers to ensure that ministerial commitments to make amendments are implemented by departments as soon as reasonably possible. The Committee will be examining the issue of delay in implementing undertakings. Delays can undermine the whole basis of honour on which the Committee withdraws notices of motion. As far as present matters are concerned, the Committee is happy with the outcome and we express our thanks to the Ministers who have assisted us with undertakings and explanations.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, for the information of honourable senators, statements setting out the cause of the Committee's scrutiny of these particular instruments.
Leave granted.
The statements read as follows-
Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations (Amendments) (Statutory Rules 1987 Nos. 97, 115 and 176)

These regulations impose very strict controls over the export of certain chemical compounds, and the export of a wide range of dual-use technology to Eastern-bloc countries. The Committee was principally concerned about (i) the existence of avenues of redress where ministerial permission to export was unjustifiably refused and (ii) the status of persons taking these kinds of decisions as ministerial delegates. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator the Hon. John Button has told the Committee that the discretionary decisions in question are ministerial decisions and the absence of independent review procedures is justified because of the sensitive nature of the high government policy involved. This policy relates to (i) the need for effective interim measures to control the export of chemical weapon precursors pending entry into force of a comprehensive Chemical Weapons Convention banning chemical weapons; and (ii) the need to support the strategic requirements of the Co-ordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls (Cocom) to prevent the direct or indirect export to the USSR and its associates of advanced technology capable of dual civil and military application. The Committee has accepted the Minister's view that ``It is an acknowledged exception to the general principle that administrative decisions should be reviewable on the merits, where the decisions involve ``high'' government policy, or where international relations or national security are affected''. However, the Committee draws the attention of the Senate to the important concession made by the Minister concerning the role of ministerial delegates in this sensitive area. The Minister has written:

The Committee expressed concern about the unqualified power of the Minister in both Regulations 13d and 13e to appoint persons to exercise the same unreviewable discretion as the Minister to grant export permissions. While it is considered such a discretion, when exercised by the Minister, should not be reviewable for the reasons noted previously, I accept the argument that the non-reviewability of such discretions becomes less palatable, and less acceptable, when exercised by ``non-accountable'' public servants. I therefore undertake, at the next available opportunity, to propose amendments to the relevant regulations, to effectively restrict the exercise of the Minister's powers by authorised officers to only positive grants of export permission; i.e.-where an export permission is to be refused, or where an export permission which has been granted is to be revoked, such a refusal or revocation could only be done by the Minister. In fact, I am advised this accords with current practice in both portfolios concerned; i.e. where authorised officers are inclined to refuse an export permission (no permission have been revoked to date), the matter is referred to the Minister for final decision.

The Committee thanks the Minister for undertaking to provide, in the legislation itself, for this important distinction between the personal roles and involvement of the Minister and those of his or her delegate in decisions that are not reviewable.

The Committee has accepted the Minister's view about the inappropriateness of independent merits review of high-policy ministerial decisions. The Minister will, of course, carry responsibility for refusals to allow certain exports to certain destinations. The economic implications of refusals to individual Australian exporters will be obvious. They are, of course, outweighed by the requirements of international and strategic obligations. In the midst of this high policy arena however, there will be high-technology exporters some of whom, at some time may consider that they have been dealt with unfairly or erroneously on the facts or on the law. Therefore the Committee urges the Minister to ensure that necessarily strict procedures and decision making will not prevent bona fide exporters having the opportunity to make appropriate representations on matters that might be subject to different interpretations, for example, the nature of the goods to be exported and the bona fides of the importer. Such internal procedures would not prejudice security.
An Order dated 29 May 1987, made under Section 6 of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974

The Committee raised with the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator the Hon. Graham Richardson, 7 issues of concern to it regarding these Orders. Firstly, it appeared that the Minister's Department was empowered to ``determine on behalf of the Minister that the preparation . . . of an environmental impact statement or a public environment report in relation to . . . proposed action [that might affect the environment] is not required for the purpose of achieving the object of the Act''. The Committee was concerned to ensure that such a crucial Departmental decision-making role was performed in a way which guaranteed the Minister's personal involvement in important matters. The Minister has explained that annually for the past 2 years his Department has received several hundred proposals which could possibly fall under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Less than 100 were eventually determined to be environmentally significant and these generated less than 10 Environmental Impact Statements (EIS). However, information on proposals submitted to the Department is submitted to the Minister on a weekly basis to provide an advance warning of proposals. Further, whenever the Department is in any doubt over the issue of not requiring an EIS, for example where the decision is marginal or where there may be political or other sensitivities involved, the Department brings the matter to the Minister's attention for resolution. At the request of the Committee the Minister has undertaken to formalise this crucial, but informal, administrative practice by issuing a formal instrument of instruction to his Department requiring the regular submission of reports on doubtful and marginal cases and other relevant matters. Environmental impact is a most sensitive issue. The Committee's concern was to ensure that delegated legislation in the form of these Orders did not either deliberately or inadvertently encourage a situation to arise where ministerial control of significant departmental decision-making was less disciplined than the Minister himself would expect when fully appraised of these matters. Active, personal, ministerial control of and responsibility for, large or difficult environmental policy issues is potentially the single most effective means of monitoring and improving the quality of administrative decision-making and its attendant processes. Through direct ministerial accountability to Parliament, any failure in the quality of top level policy making and related public administration can be more effectively scrutinised by Parliament itself. The Committee is satisfied with the Minister's decision to formalise the current practice which directly places on the Minister responsibility for the more important decisions not to require Environmental Impact Statements or Public Environmental Reports.

Secondly, the new Order introduces an alternative procedure to that of requiring an Environment Impact Statement, involving a Public Environment Report. The Committee was concerned that the Order did not make it clear when an EIS would be prepared and when a PER, which would be less detailed, would be drafted, thus creating an area of hidden and unreviewable discretion at the heart of the process for determining the quality and extent of the impact assessment procedures. In his letter to the Committee the Minister has given some informal guidance on the distinction between an EIS and a PER based essentially on the scale of the proposals. The Committee accepts that the development of workable criteria will take time and that the differences between the alternative procedures will become clearer over time. In order to meet the Committee's concern on this point the Minister has agreed to produce guidelines to assist all concerned in predicting and making the choice of alternative procedures.
In his letter to the Committee, the Minister wrote:

I would also expect that, within the next two years as a result of more experience in administering the PER process, my Department will publish guidelines, aimed at assisting both proponents and the public as to when one or other of these two forms of environmental documentation might be required. I will keep the Committee informed of progress in preparing these guidelines, I do not think it possible to predict ahead of preparation whether these guidelines would be suitable for inclusion in the Procedures, or whether such a course would be practicable. I am prepared, however, to give this matter further consideration in the light of experience.

The Committee thanks the Minister for his willingness to address this issue in this empirical and forthright way and for his courtesy in agreeing to keep the Committee appraised of developments. The Committee expresses its hope that dependable guidelines might emerge well within the two years time table and that the Minister may see the legal and declaratory value of entrenching these in the law.

Thirdly, the Committee wanted to ensure that interested members of the public could have proper access to relevant decisions and documents. The Minister has agreed to make amendments to the Orders to provide for the publication of certain matters in the Gazette and to make it quite clear that upon receipt of a written request certain information will be supplied to a querist by the originator of the proposals, the Department, or the Minister.

Fourthly, the Order contains a significant general obligation to make a draft EIS or PER available to the general public. However, that obligation is seriously limited by conferral on the Minister of a discretion to direct that the drafts be not made available. The Committee considered that any exercise of such a power should be by means of a ministerial instrument that would come before the Parliament for scrutiny. The Minister was sympathetic in principle to this suggestion though cautious that it should not lead to making public matters of national security or commercial confidence which might constitute the reasons for suppressing draft statements or reports. The Minister proposes two alternative solutions: (i) expressly require the Minister, when exempting drafts from public availability, to take into account whether publication would be prejudicial to national security, the interests of Australia, commercial confidences or be otherwise contrary to the public inte-rest; and expressly require the publication in the gazette of a summary of reasons for the actual decision; or (ii) table in Parliament an appropriate Ministerial Certificate provided this did not allow for the inadvertent disclosure of the sensitive information which the exemption process is designed to protect. The Minister has undertaken to make appropriate amendments to implement the first solution, while consulting with his Ministerial colleagues on the security aspects of tabling a ministerial certificate. The Committee has agreed to accept the Minister's interim solution. It does introduce an element of protection from undue suppression of information, and the Committee agrees that the security implications of the general issue require careful assessment.

While the Committee will await the outcome of the Minister's further examination, it notes that there should be no greater risk of the disclosure of national security or commercial-in-confidence information in the second, parliamentary based, proposal than in the first gazette based proposal. The Committee recognises that it may be inappropriate to provide for a power to disallow a certificate of exemption that was personally directed by the Minister for national security or clear commercial-in-confidence reasons and reported to Parliament. The Committee does not concede this lightly. As a matter of principle, legislation providing for complex schemes that are generally protective of the rights of individuals, should not be capable of ministerial suspension or exemption unless that is achieved by a ministerial instrument subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament. An unfettered discretion to suspend or exempt certain cases from the operation of legislation tends to undermine the uncertainty and predictability of that legislation in an unacceptable way. The appropriate remedy is independent merits review or parliamentary oversight. In its scrutiny of, for example, section 19 of the A.C.T. Credit Ordinance, the Committee requested proper parliamentary oversight of the exemption power (See the Committee's Seventy-seventh Report, P.P. No. 172/1986 page 34. See also Senator Richardson's letter of 3 November 1987 to Senator Harradine on a similar matter. Senate Daily Hansard, 3 November 1987, page 1594). It may be that a decision certified to Parliament (no less than the Gazette) as having been taken as national security grounds or commercial-in-confidence grounds, is a reasonable exception to this principle.
Fifthly, the Minister has agreed to amend the Order to leave no doubt that where reasons for decisions are to be given these will be in writing.

Sixthly, the Committee was concerned about the Minister's power to determine who would constitute ``the public'' for the purposes of certain discussions about a proposed action. A wide discretion such as this would leave room for allegations of unfairness or discrimination if certain persons or groups were excluded from participation. On the other hand some control is needed over large numbers of people who might include persons intent on disrupting the consultation process. The Committee has suggested that a nomination or representation scheme should be considered to allow persons who have expressed an interest to attend discussions personally or be represented by a nominee. The Minister has told the Committee:

. . . I would intend to write, within the context of paragraph 6.6.2., to community groups, representative of the opinion and constituency identified by the public comments on the proposal, and ask them to nominate representatives who might attend a ``round-table'' discussion. This procedure is not without its difficulties and, in recognition of this, I shall ask my Department to prepare and publish guidelines to assist in the identification of representative members of the public to attend these discussions. I would hope that this could be done within 6 months and will keep the Committee informed of progress.

Finally, the Orders contain a general ministerial power of exemption which permits a Department to request the Minister to exempt a proposed action from the entirety of the administrative procedures. The Minister must take into account the national security and commercial confidence criteria referred to earlier, as well as the general principle that it is in the national interest that the administrative procedures should always apply as far as reasonably possible. The Minister is required to make public the reasons for an exemption unless satisfied that to do so would be contrary to the public interest. The Committee is very concerned about this provision which, on its face, is contrary to the general principle referred to above concerning suspensory and exemption powers. The Committee is particularly concerned about the withholding of reasons for granting an exemption. The Committee notes that since 1975 there have been only 11 exemptions granted under the predecessor to this provision and in all cases the decisions and reasons appeared in the Gazette. However, in addressing this matter the Committee is not unmindful of the Senate's recent decision to reject in a Bill a ministerial power to suppress the reasons for issuing a direction to a statutory authority in circumstance where the existence of the direction itself would also be suppressed (Senate Daily Hansard, 27 October 1987, page 1321 re former subclause 29 (4) of the Australian Tourist Commission Bill 1987). The Committee recognises that national security matters could quite properly cause the Minister to exempt a proposal from some or all of the procedures without giving reasons. In his letter the Minister has told the Committee:

While I agree that withholding notification of exemptions and the reasons for such exemptions as permitted by paragraph 11.5 should only be exercised after full and proper scrutiny, there may be occasions when, for national security or similar national interest reasons, such exemptions may need to be granted. To allow for such cases, appropriate provisions must be made in the Procedures. However, I recognise that the grounds of ``in the public interest'', while acceptable in 1975, may raise concern in 1987. I will therefore undertake to discuss the whole matter of paragraph 11.5 with the Attorney-General and other relevant Ministers with a view to deciding whether or not the provision is necessary and, if it is, making the wording more accurately reflect the objective to be achieved. These discussions will also encompass the issue raised in the fourth point of the Chairman's letter concerning withholding all or part of a draft EIS from public review for security or commercial confidence reasons. I will keep the Committee advised of the progress of these discussions.

In the circumstances the Committee has agreed to accept this on the basis that the Committee expects that it will be kept informed and that a serious attempt will be made to provide for proper parliamentary oversight in appropriate cases. The Committee considers that the Minister's personal intention to seriously address this important issue is reflected in his statement ``. . . I agree that withholding notification of exemptions and the reasons for such exemptions as permitted by paragraph 11.5 should only be exercised after full and proper scrutiny. . .''.
Public Services Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1987 No. 90)

These Regulations provide for the transfer of Senior Executive Service officers within the Service. The Committee was interested to know principally whether a reasonable period of advance notice was given to an officer about to be transferred and whether a Secretary's power to veto an appeal against a direction to act in another job was subject to proper criteria. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, the Hon. Ralph Willis, M.P., has informed the Committee that no minimum period of notice is expressed in the regulations because SES officers will have been consulted in relation to a proposed transfer at an early stage and the underlying philosophy of the SES, embodied in the Public Service Act itself, is one of enhanced mobility. The Minister has also informed the Committee that the veto power is essential to allow Secretaries to be able to determine whether it is in the interests of efficient management for an officer to cease performing duties and temporarily perform other duties. An officer who thinks that he or she has been unfairly treated in relation to availability for temporary performance may lodge a grievance which, if disallowed by the Secretary, may be considered by the Merit Protection and Review Agency. The process will reduce the likelihood of an SES officer being subjected to unfair or biased treatment.
Australian Citizenship Regulations (Amendments) (Statutory Rules 1987 Nos. 87 and 88)

The Committee was concerned that by an unreviewable discretionary process Australians overseas who had lost original citizenship documents could still be refused copies of those documents, namely extracts from the Register of Australian Citizenship by Descent and declaratory certificate of citizenship. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Hon. Mick Young, M.P., informed the Committee that strict controls were needed over access to certain documents because they could be put to fraudulent use by criminals. The Committee shared the Minister's concern that the procedures should prevent the issue of documentation that was already in existence in circumstances where it could be put to criminal use in obtaining passports, benefits etc. However, the Committee considered that where a bona fide person had genuinely lost original documents and failed to persuade an authorised officer to exercise his or her discretion to issue copies there should be some internal, reconsideration mechanism which would allow a senior authorised officer to review the facts. Such an internal procedure would assist in underwriting the quality of authorised officers' initial decisions. At the same time it appeared to the Committee to be unlikely that a criminally motivated person would request copies of documents that were not in fact lost and, on being refused, willingly submit himself or herself to a self-initiated reconsideration process that would probe into the matter. In its letter to the Minister of 18 November 1987 the Committee wrote: ``. . . [T]he Committee has a firm commitment to the idea that the avoidance of unnecessary grievance by means of appropriate internal procedures promotes justice and skilled decision-making in the interests of Australia and Australians overseas.'' In his letter of today's date the Minister has agreed to the Committee's request to amend the regulation to provide for internal reconsideration rights. While external review rights might have been the ideal, the Committee has to look at the practicalities of the situation where Australians overseas should, where possible, have the same rights as Australians in Australia. Legally guaranteed internal reconsideration rights seem to come closest to this. The Committee hopes that any weaknesses or shortcomings in the use of an internal reconsideration procedure will come to light in a way which allows the Committee to act decisively again to protect the rights of citizens.

The Committee is grateful to the Ministers who have answered its queries, the officials who have advised the Secretariat on all of the above issues and, by no means least, its present acting legal adviser, Professor Dennis Pearce of the Australian National University, whose professional assistance to the Committee is a vital dimension of its operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the recent sabotage of Telecom Australia cables in the Sydney central business district (CBD). Can the Minister explain why it was apparently so easy for someone to sever vital Telecom cables in the Sydney CBD which had the potential to jeopardise Australia's entire telecommunications network? What assurances can the Minister give to guard against any future acts of sabotage of the telecommunications network, particularly in view of the plans by Telecom to lay high volume traffic optical fibre cables across the entire continent over the next 10 years? Does the Minister consider the current backup arrangements adequate in the event of a full scale breakdown in the terrestrial telecommunications network? Further, does the Minister consider that the Aussat satellite system could be better utilised to ensure the security of Australia's nationwide telecommunications system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case, as we all know, that on the night of Friday, 20 November, 24 cables carrying up to 35,000 circuits through the Haymarket, Pitt, York and City South exchanges were cut at 10 different locations under the city of Sydney. The cables affected are in an area bounded by Martin Place, Kent Street, Chinatown, Regent Street and Ultimo Road. The damage, which is estimated at several million dollars, occurred when someone, manifestly with a detailed knowledge of the underground tunnel system and the local, junction, optical fibre and coaxial cables, entered the tun- nels and attacked the cables apparently with an angle grinder and an axe. Telecom linesmen, engineers and technicians mounted a major round the clock operation to repair the damaged cables and restore services which did leave thousands of customers, including major business houses, without communications of both telephones and special services such as data links.

ANSWER.PARA: Telecom has now provided temporary services for 70 per cent of the 15,000 telephone and data lines affected. Most of the remaining problems are centred in offices around the very busy Martin Place region. Full repair and restoration of these services could take several more days. Of course the Government, as well as Telecom itself, views most seriously any outside interference with the network, let alone a destructive and disruptive incident on this scale.

Telecom's security and investigation branch, together with the New South Wales Police, is carrying out an exhaustive investigation of the incident and they are liaising with the Australian Federal Police. In addition, security patrols of the tunnels have been stepped up, and a number of immediate measures have been put in place to make entrances to the tunnel system more easily secured. The reason why those tunnel entrances were not as well secured as they might have been has, I think, become quite apparent in public statements by the Operations Manager of Telecom and it is because of an anxiety about safety and ease of egress in the event of an emergency situation as far as the workmen are concerned. Telecom has today announced a reward of $50,000 for information leading to the conviction of those persons responsible for the sabotage.

I should say in terms of the larger issue that Telecom has been working for some time already to improve the security of its public network. In March this year a major in-house review of network security was initiated. This review has reached the stage where problems and potential threats have been identified. The review is now moving into the solutions stage and, at my request, its work is being accelerated following Friday's incident. This process should be completed early in the new year, and measures to further protect the integrity of the network will then be carried out.

As to the last part of the question as to the role that Aussat and the satellite system might play in avoiding problems of this kind in the future, I think the answer speaks for itself that it is only as a marginal addition to the basic Telecom network that we can expect Aussat to be playing a role in the reasonably foreseeable future. When it comes to the major intercity links and the major intracity network connections of the kind that were in issue here it is difficult to see Aussat playing any role that could possibly substitute for the cabling that was under attack here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The last part of the question referred to the backup generally, Aussat being one possible opportunity to provide backup. What plans does the Government have to ensure that there is backup in these situations if they should occur again?

—The way the network is constructed a very large number of backup routes and circuits are available as alternative means by which data, telephony and so on can be routed. Whether it is possible to develop backup on any greater scale than exists at the moment as a solution to the security problem is something that I will raise with Telecom to see whether that cannot be incorporated into the review process, if that makes any sense.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to the transcript of an interview by Laurie Oakes of the Opposition economic spokesperson, Andrew Peacock, on the Sunday program yesterday, in which Mr Peacock reaffirmed the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia to abolish the fringe benefits tax (FBT)? What would be the cost to revenue if the fringe benefits tax were abolished? What options would be available, as Mr Peacock implied, for avoiding going back to `the situation where the so-called rorts continue' if the fringe benefits tax were abolished?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not actually seen the transcript nor did I see the program, but I have read a couple of Press reports and, as the Press reports seem to be consistent with each other, I assume that they are basically correct. In regard to revenue, the Budget estimate for fringe benefits tax receipts for this financial year is $750m. However, that does not tell the whole story. If the rort of converting what should be paid and would otherwise be paid as wages or salaries into fringe benefits were to be reopened there is no doubt that there would be a major conversion of income presently received as wages and salaries into fringe benefits, should fringe benefits again become non-taxable. Although it is speculative, as to the degree to which acting on Mr Peacock's policies would increase the cost to revenue beyond the $750m, there is no doubt that that would happen and, I think, there is every reason to believe that the cost, in the first year even, would be a few hundred million dollars, blowing out probably by a few hundred million dollars for each subsequent year until it eventually ran into $2 billion or $3 billion, if the rort were to be reopened in the way that Mr Peacock seems to be suggesting.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot think of any way of collecting tax on income received in kind which is more efficient than the FBT arrangements the Government has put in place. But I have been asked what other alternatives would be available. One alternative which would be available would be to require all employers to state on the employee's group certificate the value of income paid in kind and, in addition, as group certificates already require, income paid in cash. Small employers who do not issue group certificates would be required to buy taxation stamps for the income paid in kind instead of in cash. Of course, that would be an enormous additional work load for those in the private sector if they were required to provide details of every type of non-cash remuneration paid to every employee instead of lodging bulk returns as they do now.

If one just looks at the revenue collected, that system could have the potential advantage of there being no exemptions to fringe benefits tax or income received in kind instead of case; and that, other things being equal, would boost the revenue. However, the cost incurred by the private sector in administering the vastly more complicated arrangements which Mr Peacock seems to be proposing would probably reduce the profits of companies and other taxpayers to the point where that revenue gain would be more than wiped out. In other words, on both efficiency and equity grounds, I would suggest that that alternative method is vastly inferior to the arrangements put in place by the Government. I noticed in the same Press reports that, although Mr Peacock was hedging his bets to some extent on the rorting of the taxation system through the payment of fringe benefits, he remained unequivocal and re-endorsed his 1984 commitment to continue paying pensions to millionaires. That, of course, would require higher taxes instead of the lower taxes the Liberal Party is proposing, unless Mr Peacock is also proposing to blow out the Budget deficit-which, I note for the record, is precisely what the coalition Government did, to a grossly irresponsible extent, during its last year in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Minister aware of the widespread community concern in the upper north of South Australia caused by the impending closure of the Port Pirie Education Centre (Inc.) as a result of the Federal Government withdrawing for 1988 its base grant funding under the education centre program? Did the Commonwealth Schools Commission verbally recommend that the Port Pirie centre be included in a recommended 26 centres for continued funding in 1988? Is the centre's utility further recognised by the fact that at the very time the Government has withdrawn funding, another section of the same Department, in the form of the Commonwealth Employment Service, has contracted for the centre to run its job search program next year? Furthermore, did the same Department recently approve a community employment program (CEP) grant to the centre of some $50,000 to improve its grounds, while again during the same period forcing its closure next year through its withdrawal of base grant funding? How can the Government justify wasting some $50,000 of CEP funds in this way-an amount which would have been sufficient to keep the centre operating for another year? Is the failure by the Government to establish rational spending priorities a further example of this Government's managerial incompetence or an example of its contempt for underprivileged rural and isolated people?

—I have a brief note on this matter which I will make available to the Senate. Insofar as there are six or seven elements of the question asked by Senator Chapman, at the end of my answer I may refer the question to the Minister for a more detailed response. In the brief available to me, the note reads that the reductions to the education centre's program in the 1986-87 Budget were made in the context of the need to reduce overall expenditure within the public sector. The Government chose to maintain the maximum number of centres possible whilst sustaining a viable network serving both rural and urban areas. The Port Pirie Education Centre subsequently received assistance under the projects of national significance program, administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission, to support a policy development project concerned with rural schooling, with particular focus on the needs of girls. The grant was not offered as an alternative to recurrent funding. It is open to all education centres to seek additional funding from a variety of sources to support and enhance their operations. Without accepting the colouring which tinted some of the elements of the question put by Senator Chapman, I will undertake to seek a further and more detailed response to the various elements of his question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for the Environment and the Arts to reports of the concern expressed by the Tasmanian Government about the possible need to fight fires in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests. Is the Tasmanian Minister for Forests correct in assuming that the Commonwealth is so intransigent as not to allow reasonable fire protection to take place? Has the Commonwealth made assessments of the likelihood of fire in the Lemonthyme and Southern forests this summer? Is the Commonwealth required to contribute towards the cost of fire prevention preparations? What response has the Minister given to Mr Groom's request to undertake firefighting precautions? In particular, and in the light of the Minister's wholehearted support for protecting Australia's natural heritage, I ask for his response to Mr Groom's quoted assertion:

QUESTION.PARA: I do not believe Senator Richardson would lose one wink of sleep if the Lemonthyme and southern forests were burnt out during the coming summer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coates for his question. If the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests were destroyed this summer I would lose more than a wink of sleep. The telephone would never let me sleep because of organisations ringing up to complain. Apart from that, having visited the area I know it is magnificent with values that are worth preserving. I would always be greatly saddened if we were to lose any of it. I heard of Mr Groom's complaints and requests on the radio and I read them in the paper a couple of days before I received a letter, so he can now hear of my response a couple of days before he gets my letter in reply.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth in fact argued in the High Court of Australia that forestry operations in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests would contribute greatly to fire risks and that was one reason why we should prevent them and why there ought to be a stay of proceedings for logging in the area. Further to that, obviously the Commonwealth, in setting aside that area for protection during the Helsham inquiry, the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry, is well and truly aware of the values of the area and would not like to see them degraded in any way. The Commonwealth has never intended to stop fire control activities and does not now. Commonwealth responsibilities fall a long way short of financing the normal responsibilities of State governments. It remains the responsibility of the Tasmanian Government to control-and, indeed, pay for that control-the fire risk in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests and the Commonwealth has no intention of making any special grant for the purpose. I think I would have to say to Senator Coates that the Minister's statement was a media stunt try on. It will not work and the Commonwealth will continue to look for an appropriate Tasmanian response.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not learnt a thing since you became a Minister.

—I have not learnt a thing in a few years; it has taken Senator Walters a lifetime to learn nothing and she does it in style. I insist that the Tasmanian Government continue to maintain its fire control responsibilities and would hope that after this answer it gets on with the job.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Further to my question last Friday on organochlorine residues in Australian beef, I ask: What stocks of contaminated beef are held, in what quantities and where are these stocks currently located? Has the Minister seen a report in today's Age newspaper in which it is stated that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) Board is to meet shortly to decide what to do with the contaminated meat now held in storage in the United States, with one of the options being the sale of that meat, at a reduced price, possibly to Eastern bloc or north African countries? In the light of the Minister's reply to my question of Friday last, what control is the Government able to exercise over the disposal of consignments of contaminated Australian meat held in storage both overseas and in Australia? What action will the Government take if the AMLC Board should decide to seek buyers for contaminated beef in countries which may have less stringent systems of inspection than the United States and Japan?

—I did see that report in the Age. I must confess that I did not contemplate it for any length of time, but my quick impression was that there was some discrepancy or difficulty in reconciling the various figures within it, such as a reference to, I think it was, 2,000 tonnes of beef and a reference to $50m. If 2,000 tonnes is the total, I cannot reconcile those two figures. But I will get information on that. I did also note that it was reported that the AMLC is contemplating disposing of that stock to countries-specifically to the Eastern bloc; I am not quite sure what that means, but it was the term used-which do not have very stringent requirements. I gather from the tone of Senator Jenkins's question that she disapproves of that. Personally, providing there is a full and accurate disclosure of the alleged contamination, I do not see anything particularly wrong with giving a buyer the option of purchasing at a discounted price if the buyer so wishes. It is, of course, essential in doing that, for both commercial and, if it has any relevance, moral reasons that there be a full and accurate disclosure of what is in the meat. However, I can, of course, understand that there are some people with an authoritarian turn of mind who would prefer not to give people the option of purchasing a product which some other people regard as being inferior or contaminated in some way. They would prefer such people to have no option other than to have no beef at all if they cannot afford the asking price for a product that is supposed not to be contaminated. That is a view that is fashionable in authoritarian bourgeois circles. It is not one that greatly attracts me.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. I draw Senator Walsh's attention to elements in my question to which he has not responded. What stocks of contaminated beef are currently held in Australia and where are they held?
—I thought that I had covered that in the earlier part of my answer. I do not know, but I will try to get that information from Mr Kerin.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the Minister aware of a report published last week in Britain which claims that the risks of fatal cancer from low level radiation have been greatly underestimated? Is he also aware that, as a result of that report, the British National Radiological Protection Board has called for the permitted safe level of exposure of the general public to radiation to be halved, and that of workers to be cut by two-thirds? Will the Australian Government re- examine its own controls over radiation in the light of that report?
—Mr President--
—You are in trouble, aren't you?

—I shall take a little punt on this. I am sure that the Minister would be very well aware of the report which Senator Childs has drawn to the attention of the Senate. Without giving any undertakings as to the consequent action upon a review, I am sure that a further review will be undertaken to allow the fears and misgivings that Senator Childs has quite rightly drawn to the attention of the Senate to be allayed in an expert manner.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Local Government aware of the great concern being expressed by three of Tasmania's largest councils-namely, the cities of Hobart, Glenorchy and Launceston, which together account for almost half of Tasmania's population-that they are to receive reductions in Commonwealth funding in excess of $1m over the next five years? On 2 November, in answer to a previous question asked by me, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is a new system which the majority of local authorities have welcomed because it is a more equitable process of distribution.
Does the Minister still hold this view, and will she be explaining this equitable process to these cities when she visits them later this week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important that Senator Calvert take up the invitation that I issued a couple of weeks ago for him to come and have the system explained to him so that he is in a better position of understanding.
—Why not explain it to the Senate?

—Let me explain it to the Senate. First of all, the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance reported to Parliament about the best possible way of redistributing local government funding, and I would remind Opposition senators that that report had bipartisan support, and when the new legislation went through last year, it also had bipartisan support. What happens in the process of Commonwealth funding going to the States is that each State has to submit a set of broad principles for the more equitable distribution of Commonwealth funding-the Commonwealth has accepted the principles that were submitted by Tasmania-and the State Grants Commission then takes over to allocate those funds in the most equitable way.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Calvert has raised the concerns of three councils-Glenorchy, Hobart and Launceston-and he is correct in saying that I shall be talking to each of those councils this week. However, we have to remember that it is very unwise to look too far into the future at just what will happen in regard to funding, because populations can change, valuations can change and recommendations to States grants commissions can change. I look forward to talking to those three councils. The recommendations that were submitted this year with respect to them were in accordance with the principles of distribution. The recommendations involved only three councils-Hobart, Glenorchy and Waratah-incurring actual losses in the current financial year, the greatest of which was only 6.9 per cent. What we have to remember is that, historically, throughout Australia a number of councils have been disadvantaged over many years.

I seem to remember that Senator Calvert or Senator Chapman raised the question of rural councils. Professor Self recommended that there should be a redistribution which looked at those councils on a needs basis. Whether or not a number of capital cities and the larger councils like it-of course, I do not expect them to like the potential for some changes in emphasis in the distribution of funds-the reality is that capital cities have done very well over the years since Gough Whitlam introduced funding to local government. Some councils, especially those in growth areas and a number of rural areas, have not been getting the attention they deserve. The focus of the Self inquiry was on trying to bring about a more equitable system throughout Australia.

However, in relation to the three councils that Senator Calvert has mentioned, I am fortunate in that I will have an opportunity to visit them this week. I will certainly take up their concerns with my colleague the Tasmanian Minister. I remind Senator Calvert that the Commonwealth has the broad focus to accept principles, but State grants commissions have to make the ultimate determination on the most equitable basis set down by those principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware of the misleading statements made by her Labor colleague Duncan Kerr who `slammed the decision' and called on the Grants Commission to find a more equitable grant payment structure? Does the Minister agree that Duncan Kerr is condemning the State Grants Commission when it is the Commonwealth guidelines that are in question? Will the Minister be offering Duncan Kerr the same invitation as the Minister offered both Senator Panizza and me when she invited us to `a full briefing of the new arrangements for local government funding'?
—Senator Reynolds will answer that part of the question which is a proper supplementary.

—I think you will agree, Mr President, that Senator Calvert has raised a number of other issues that relate to the first question. As you have given me the call, Mr President, I am quite happy to answer them. I am aware that Mr Duncan Kerr has made his concerns known, as well he should, in regard to representing Glenorchy and Hobart in his electorate. He wants to sit down and discuss this question with me. As I said earlier in answer to Senator Calvert, I will certainly be raising these concerns with my counterpart in Tasmania. It has to be remembered that it is the State Grants Commission to which Senator Calvert should be directing his concerns, because it is the State Grants Commission that ultimately determines the distribution. The Commonwealth only accepts the broad principles.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LOCAL GOVERNMENT: SYDNEY CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Local Government aware that a commission of inquiry into the system of government in the city of Sydney was appointed by the New South Wales Government? Is the Minister aware that the first report of the inquiry recommended that the Sydney central business district and some of the adjoining residential areas be constituted as an area known as Sydney central? Is the Minister aware that the government of Sydney central would be in the hands of a board known as the Sydney central commission? Is the Minister aware that the report recommends that all commissioners be appointed by the Premier of New South Wales? Does the Minister agree with the system of elected local governments in Australia being replaced by State government appointed commissions? Will the Minister condemn the inquiry's recommendations as the end to democratic local government in Australia's second oldest local government area? Will the Minister express support for democratic local government in central Sydney to her New South Wales counterpart? In passing, she may answer the question whether the State Government of New South Wales answers the description of `bourgeois authoritarian', as defined by Senator Walsh.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did answer this question last week when it was raised, I think, by Senator Calvert. I said on that occasion that I totally supported the principle of democratic, elected local government, and went on to indicate that it was for that reason that I was a strong advocate of constitutional recognition so that we could see Federal, State and local authorities working in closer co-operation and consultation. I also said at that time that I understood that the indication of establishing a central commission-that is, commissioners appointed by the New South Wales Government-was in actual fact only a recommendation at that stage.

ANSWER.PARA: I have expressed my concerns about the alarming precedent that would be involved if the New South Wales Government were to accept that particular recommendation. However, I am pleased to report-and I refer to a Press report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 November-that the commission plan is to be dumped. The report states that State Cabinet is expected to reject a controversial plan for a fully appointed commission to run Sydney, that Government sources had that day confirmed that there were some problems with the plan and that Cabinet was meeting to fully discuss the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Window dressing for the State election! What do you think about that? Give us a considered view on that.

—Senator Michael Baume interjects about windows and dressing. I am not sure what he is referring to. The fact of the matter is that the New South Wales Government commissioned a report; it received a report; it is currently discussing and making its final decision about that report; and when the New South Wales Government has made that decision, we will all be in a position to make up our minds about what we think of its final decision. I am confident that the New South Wales Government will fully take into account the principles involved in terms of democratic local government elections, and I reserve any further comment until Cabinet has fully reported.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Local Government. Has the Minister consulted with the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support as to the long term financial effect of current road funding trends on the budgets of country local authorities? Will the Minister direct her Department to examine the effects on the budgets of the non-metropolitan local authorities in Western Australia which are faced with a real loss of 70 per cent of 1985-86 Federal Government road funding by 1994-95 if the report of the Cameron Independent Committee of Inquiry into the Distribution of Federal Road Grants is implemented and Federal road funding remains constant in nominal terms only?
—The answer is yes, I have been in consultation with my colleague who is responsible for road funding; and the detail of that question should be referred to Senator Evans.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, relates to the Government's recently announced ban on smoking on all commercial domestic aircraft. I ask this question in the knowledge that the Government has responded to many public demands and to a majority decision of the Federal parliamentary Labor Caucus that such measures be put in place. Accepting that one of the arguments used by those in favour of the Government's decision is the health hazard posed to non-smokers, I ask: Has the Government based its decision on medical or scientific evidence? If so, what was that evidence? Has the Government instituted or commissioned any of its own studies or surveys? Finally, it has also been argued that smoking on aircraft has a substantial impact on the cost of servicing and maintaining aircraft, an impact which is paid for by the consumer. Now that the decision to ban smoking has been made, I ask the Minister when he expects these savings to be passed on to air travellers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, when I announced that I would take a proposal to Cabinet to seek approval to institute a ban on all domestic airline flight smoking, I indicated that quite apart from the likely adverse health effects of passive smoking there was ample justification for such a ban on the ground of distress and discomfort to non-smoking passengers. But there is, nonetheless, a major health justification for the ban. The ban is in line with the objectives of the national campaign against drug abuse, it is in accordance with the recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council 1986 working party report on the effects of passive smoking on health, and it does have strong support, as has become apparent in recent days and weeks, from the medical profession generally.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has received representations from a number of medical organisations supporting the ban, including the Australian Medical Association, the Public Health Association of Australia and New Zealand, the Australasian Epidemiological Association, the West Australian Professional Health Educators Association, the National Heart Foundation, the Thoracic Society of Australia, the National Health and Medical Research Unit in Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine, the Queensland Cancer Fund and a number of individual medical practitioners-including, Senator Walsh, even some members of the Australian Capital Territory doctors union.

There has been research undertaken overseas on smoking in aircraft. The US National Academy of Science's National Research Council report in 1986 did recommend a ban on smoking to reduce potential health hazards to cabin crew, as well as for three other reasons: to lessen irritation to passengers and crew, to eliminate the possibility of fires caused by cigarettes and to bring cabin air quality into line with established standards for other closed environments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get rid of grog? Be fair dinkum.
—That might help to get Senator Ray's weight down.
—Cheap populism!

—It was not Senator Ryan who called me a Left fascist, Senator Button. The Sixth World Conference on Smoking on Health in Tokyo from 9 to 12 October this year made a recommendation concerning enforced smoking and non-smokers' rights in the following terms:

ANSWER.PARA: All countries should work towards establishing smoke-free environments in all enclosed public places, particularly work sites, transport, health-care facilities, schools and child-care facilities.

In addition, bans on smoking have been recommended by the World Health Organisation at its thirty-ninth World Health Assembly in May 1986 and by the United States Surgeon General in his 1986 report on the health consequences of involuntary smoking.

As to the last part of the question, the Government has not undertaken any surveys of passenger preference, but it is clear from the current ratios of smoking and non-smoking seats provided by the airlines that the overwhelming majority of passengers do prefer non-smoking seats, and certainly representations that the Government has received on this issue have been strongly in favour of such a ban. Might I also mention in terms of the commercial implications of this, and it is something I propose to draw to the attention of Qantas Airways Ltd, that Niki Lauda, who runs Lauda Airlines, the Austrian applicant for rights into Australia, told me a couple of weeks ago that he is proposing to make his 767 flight to the Far East and Australia a non-smoking international flight-the first of its kind, I understand, in the world-because of his research which indicates that more people will take the flight specifically for that reason than would be deterred from doing so by virtue of the ban. There are no precise figures available as to any savings that might be achieved in the servicing and maintenance of aircraft as a result of the ban. However, I would have to say in response to that part of Senator McKiernan's question that I would not expect them to be of sufficient magnitude to result in decreases in air fares.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Transport and Communications relates to the answer that he has just given. In light of the seriousness with which he regards the risk to the health of people on aeroplanes, why has he continued to expose service personnel who man the VIP flights to those health hazards, given that he is not prepared to see the rest of Australia subjected to that indignity?
—That is a very reasonable question. I will refer it to the Prime Minister.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to an article in the Australian newspaper entitled: `Telecom seeks ties with Aussat, OTC'. In that article, Telecom's Chief Manager, Bob McKinnon, was reported as saying that closer co-operation was needed between the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC), Telecom Australia and Aussat Pty Ltd because of the size of the domestic telecommunications market. Does the Minister agree with this statement? Does the Government agree that closer co- operation could lead to a mutual sharing of difficult but related expertise?

—There is a view that has been around since at least the 1974 report of the Vernon Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Post Office that the provision of domestic and international communications should be provided by one organisation. Telecom's views on this matter to that effect are well known and have been taken into consideration by the telecommunications policy review team and the associated officials group from other departments that have been working on this matter in recent times. The reality is that OTC and Telecom in particular already work closely together, and this is formalised in a series of working agreements. The present legislative framework does allow considerable scope for the organisations to work either more closely or competitively as their respective commercial judgments lead them. The question raised by Senator Foreman is important, but I am not going to pre-empt an answer to it. The matter in issue is being closely considered at the moment by the officials group to which I referred and will be considered shortly in association with other Telecom-related policy matters by the structural adjustment committee of the Cabinet.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that responsibility for the forward equipment planning for the whole of the Defence Force has now been taken over by the Chief of the Defence Force? Why has no public announcement been made of this very important change, which I for one have been advocating for more than 10 years? Will it for the first time result in the equipment and structure of our Defence Force being dealt with as a whole, rather than as an uneasy amalgam of three separate Services? Will this change also overcome the previous system whereby the three Services separately made equipment bids and Defence Department public servants, usually without any relevant qualifications, were able to play the competing services off against each other and keep policy control in their hands? Was this divide and rule system and the consequent antagonism in the Defence Department between civilian and professional defence personnel very damaging to the efficiency of our Defence Force? Does the Force Development and Analysis Division of the Defence Department examine new equipment proposals, using operational research techniques? Finally, will this division now come directly under the Vice Chief of the Defence Force, as it obviously should, to avoid the continuation of the friction between the civilian and professional elements of the Defence Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think in respect of the first part of Senator Hamer's question, I did read something to that effect. However, I cannot remember the detail. Senator Hamer asked a lot of other questions, the basic thrust of which, I think, is that Defence civilian personnel know nothing about equipment and, in fact, activists in the field know everything. I took that as an implication of part of what the honourable senator said. However, there is no doubt that part of the thrust of his question obviously is correct, that if we can have a unified approach to equipment rather than one or other service jealously trying to promote their own interests and their own equipment, we would all be better off. When the Defence Department was merged some years ago it was quite obvious that it would take a long time to get a unified defence approach in which all the Services would co-operate and establish the correct priorities. Based on what the White Paper said and as a result of many of the other innovations of this Government, I hope that this approach will gradually evolve. There are a lot of personnel in the defence area and, naturally, it is not an easy department to administer.

ANSWER.PARA: I just note for the record that at last we now have a government that does have an overall policy and strategy in the defence area. When the Liberals were in office, the strategy seemed to be, in my view anyway, more tailored to election gimmicks than anything else. Hence we would have such proposals as buying the occasional aircraft carrier coming into an election, which would have been a very good gimmick in 1983 except the British reneged on its sale. As to the latter two points of the honourable senator's question that were a little more detailed, I will seek an answer from Mr Beazley when he gets back to the country tomorrow and hope to provide it to the honourable senator by the end of the week.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the latest employment and unemployment figures. I ask the Minister: What up to date information does he have on labour market trends in the several State economies compared with national trends? What policy factors have caused discrepancies in the State by State results?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have here some non- seasonally adjusted data on unemployment rates for Queensland and Australia in the financial years since 1983-84. Since they are for whole years, the fact that they are not seasonally adjusted should not, I think, make any difference to the relativities. They show that in that time the Australian average unemployment rate has fallen by 1.3 percentage points, while the Queensland rate has gone up by 0.2 percentage points. Thus the gap between the unemployment rates in Queensland and the rest of Australia has widened. In 1983-84 the national unemployment rates was 9.6 per cent and the Queensland rate was 9.7 per cent. By the next year the national rate had fallen to 8.6 per cent, a decline of one per cent, and Queensland's rate had gone up into double figures, above 10 per cent. In the most recent financial year-1986-87-the Australian rate was 8.6 per cent and the Queensland rate was still as high as 9.9 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the last part of the question as to what is the reason for this, various excuses have been offered about people who were already unemployed allegedly flocking into Queensland. That is contradicted by the statistics on interstate migration that are available. Another excuse which has been offered is the fact that Queensland is a mining State and to a greater degree than the Australian economy generally is a mining economy. That is inconsistent with the record in Western Australia, which is also a mining State, where employment has grown quite rapidly. I think the rather inescapable conclusion is that Queensland's employment record over recent years is attributable to the fact that it has a National Party Government run by the machine which put Senator Stone into the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I ask: When half a million Australians have difficulty in speaking English, why is the Government adding to this number by bringing in at least 40,000 migrants yearly with little or no English? I stress that they are migrants, not refugees. Why is the knowledge of English not a criterion prior to migrant entry? Why does the Government select migrants who have little or no English, thereby causing Australian taxpayers to fund tuition in English to the tune of some $50m a year?

—I do not have a brief on this subject because I think that there is bipartisan support in regard to our immigration policy. I suppose it has never been imagined that anybody would ask the kind of question that Senator Sheil has asked this afternoon. I am more than happy to take the honourable senator's question on notice, but I would have thought that, given the bipartisan support that political parties have had to immigration policy over the years, it would have been fairly apparent that providing migrant services to new citizens who come to this country is part and parcel of both Government and Opposition policy in regard--
—It is the way we are selecting migrants who immediately need the services. That is what he is asking about. Answer the question.

—Obviously this matter is raising certain divisions within the Opposition in regard to its policy on immigration. As a matter of fact on Friday I spent a very enjoyable evening with Senator Short at a conference on Asian immigration. Senator Short and I had no difference of opinion on immigration and I am sure that Senator Short would support the adult migrant education program. While the question has been directed to me I believe that it could very well be directed back to members of the Opposition to sort out the differences between the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia in regard to services for migrants. If Senator Stone and Senator Sheil are saying that only English speaking migrants should come to this country, they should stand up and say so. Apparently that is what Senator Stone believes. Senator Sheil has raised a question that I am certainly prepared to take on notice but I believe that it has highlighted a very unusual difference in philosophy among those on the other side of the chamber.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The introduction by the Australian Taxation Office of taxpayer self-assessment was intended to speed up the processing of tax returns. However, I have been informed that delays of up to 12 weeks are now being experienced by taxpayers expecting refunds, while assessment notices for underpayment of tax are being processed within six weeks. Can the Minister explain the reason for the difference of six weeks between the issue of assessment notices and refund cheques, because one could be forgiven if the immediate reaction were that the Government is employing delaying tactics in the issue of refunds to save interest payments and help the Budget debts?
—Senator Walters says that she has been informed-I do not know by whom; whether it was the fairy at the bottom of the garden or some Liberal Party of Australia tax evader.
—Are they two different creatures?

—Senator Tate asked me whether they are two different creatures. I do not know about that; I will have to take that one on notice. On the alleged delays, I will see what information I can get from the Taxation Office via the Treasurer.

—Has the Minister for Finance noted Press reports over the weekend alleging that the Government, in its negotiations with its own backbenchers over parliamentary salaries, has entered into two deals relating to future entitlements under the parliamentary Superannuation Fund Investment Trust arrangements, namely: firstly, that members and senators retiring under those arrangements in future should be entitled to receive 100 per cent of their benefits by way of lump sum rather than, as at present, only 50 per cent that way and 50 per cent by way of pension; and, secondly, that entitlements under these arrangements should in future be calculated on the basis of parliamentary salaries plus electoral allowances rather than, as at present, only parliamentary salaries? Is the Minister also aware that the Department of the Treasury is currently conducting, on the Government's behalf, a full-scale inquiry into the arrangements governing superannuation schemes in general with a view to reducing their present degree of concessionality? Against that background I ask the Minister: Firstly, are these Press reports correct? Secondly, if so, does he approve of such deals said to have been entered into by his Government?

—I have not seen any Press reports alleging that some deal, or deals, have been done, although I have not read all the newspapers, so I am not disputing that there may have been such reports. To the best of my knowledge no deal was done along the lines that Senator Stone suggested, or any deal on other lines. As yet, there has been no announcement of any government decision, but I think it is well enough known that I can say that the article which Michelle Grattan wrote in the Age last Saturday, although questionable in one or two details, is basically correct. I was asked whether I was aware or could confirm-or something like that-that a review of superannuation arrangements in general was under way. The answer, of course, is that I do know such a review is under way. I do not know what specific propositions for change the Treasury may have submitted or be submitting to the Treasurer, if any propositions at all for change are being submitted. As to whether there is any incompatibility between Press reports of Government decisions on parliamentary superannuation and other matters, I will submit that to the Treasurer for comment.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and relates to matters concerning the security and operation of the National Crime Authority (NCA). Is it accepted practice that the South Australian Attorney-General should acknowledge the existence of Operation Vigilante being conducted in South Australia by the NCA? Is it accepted practice that the South Australian Minister of Emergency Services should talk about the timetable of the NCA in South Australia, particularly that he expected a final report by the end of the year? What is the practice of the NCA in giving briefings? Is the practice consistent with the offer of the South Australian Minister of Emergency Services to arrange a briefing for senior Opposition members by the NCA-and I quote from the South Australian Hansard-`so that they will have perfect knowledge of what is going on'? Following the statement of the South Australian Premier that he was prepared to establish a royal commission into the South Australian police force if the NCA recommended such a move, I ask whether that is an appropriate function for the NCA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the method by which the South Australian Minister might make public a certain general understanding of operations being undertaken by the National Crime Authority and, in particular, those instances where the Authority has gone beyond a general investigation and is using its plenary powers under a particular reference, it is the case that already in its reports published for the Parliament the National Crime Authority in a very general way makes the scope of its references known to the general public. To know whether the South Australian Minister had gone beyond the very general description of the operation being undertaken in his apparent acknowledgment of the fact that a reference known as Vigilante may be being undertaken, I would have to see the text of his acknowledgment and the extent to which he details that operation or reference.

ANSWER.PARA: I did not make a note of the second part of the question, but it concerned whether a Minister should make a timetable, I think it was, for making a reference known to the general public. I do not think that that would normally be expected to be made known by a Minister but I am not sure to what extent that also has been indicated by the National Crime Authority. Honourable senators will be aware that certain references given very early in the life of the Authority have come or are coming to an end. The Authority has made it clear that it is moving from having some six or seven references under way to a position, over the next year or so, where that number will be reduced to three, including perhaps a major reference that will be discussed in Hobart next Thursday afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time, Senator Childs asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware of a report published last week in Britain which claims that the risks of fatal cancer from low level radiation have been greatly underestimated? During Question Time I received the following notes: The limits for exposure to radiation of workers and members of the public in Australia are recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council and generally incorporate the latest international recommendations as they are published. The recommended limits have been based principally on medical studies of the surviving populations of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, who were exposed to levels 20 to 100 times higher than the current occupational limit, and for whom it has been demonstrated that they suffer an increased risk of contracting cancer in later life.

Based on these studies, the recommended limits have implied risks of about one in 1,600 per year for workers who receive the limit and one-tenth of this figure for members of the public. In practice, however, the imposition of these respective limits, together with an obligation that exposures shall be kept as low as reasonably achievable, lead to average exposures which are generally 10 times lower. The corresponding risk is then about one in 16,000 for workers and one-tenth of this for members of the public. Very recently the estimates of doses associated with those atomic explosions have been revised and reduced to about half of earlier estimates. This implies that the risks associated with exposure are doubled, if it is assumed that the risk is strictly proportional to the dose.

The Australian Radiation Laboratory is currently reviewing this new information to determine what changes may need to be made to the Australian recommended radiation protection standards. In practice, occupational exposures in Australia are, on average, less than one-fiftieth of the current recommended limits.
