I welcome the tabling by the Government of this paper because it is important and because the information in it is significant for policy makers, both in government and elsewhere. In brief, the report, in my view, sketches a fairly unhappy picture of the population trends in Australia. We find that our population growth, at 1.46 per cent in 1986, is historically low; it is low compared with rates in most developing countries, although high compared with rates in other developed countries. That growth is really caused by immigration. The report goes on to point out that the most recent estimate of fertility in Australia-for 1986-is one of the lowest levels ever recorded, and about 10.5 per cent below long-term replacement.

It is significant that in a country as wealthy as Australia, a country with such benign living conditions, we do not increase our population. The need for immigration to ensure that we have any population growth at all is a quite stark fact that needs to be widely understood within this country.

I do not wish to go into great detail on the figures that are disclosed because time does not permit it in this brief debate, but the implications of our lack of population growth in Australia, which is reflected by the lack of population growth in other developed countries, are very large indeed.

As the report said on page 3, whereas at present only about two-thirds of people live in developing countries, by 2100 this is projected to have risen to six-sevenths of total population. So by 2100 only one-seventh of the population of the world can expect to live in what we currently describe as the developed world. Australia, which is presently the forty-fifth most populated country, could be expected to be only the sixty-eighth most populated country by 2025-a very substantial shift. We find in the report also a projection of a further decline of fertility to about 12 per cent below the long term replacement rate by the early 1990s; that is, Australia is experiencing even greater population declines than other developed countries.

Quite apart from anything else, that has major implications for welfare and retirement policy. There will be a very substantial increase in dependency unless we change either the birth rate or the immigration rate, or a bit of both. The report points out that the increase in aged dependency between 1986 and 2025 is projected to be 82 per cent, with an average annual net migration gain of 50,000, or 65 per cent, and an annual gain of 125,000. In a community that is already complaining about the levels of taxation required to maintain the existing income support systems, that is a very serious matter for this country.

The single point I wish to make is that the latter part of the report points out that the Australian Government does intentionally influence population growth through its immigration program and that, to date, no policies have been put in place to influence fertility. The report points out that policies to influence fertility by making the financial burdens easier to bear have had limited effect in both Eastern Europe and Western Europe. However, I think one would be very bold to say that the substantial financial disadvantage suffered by people with dependants was not a factor in forming attitudes towards family formation and reproduction. The Government has ample information available to it. The Institute of Family Studies has pointed out that a family with three children requires an income in excess of $50,000 to have the equivalent disposable income of the single person on average weekly earnings, equivalent to under half that amount. Many studies show the very significant financial penalties which are incurred by people who have children. Unfortunately, that is not totally cancelled out by the fact that child bearing is still a particularly joyous and happy part of the lives of the great bulk of Australians.

I simply wish to say in the few seconds that remain to me that I think it is important that governments pay greater attention to the high cost of dependency and that non-government bodies, like the Government itself, should focus also on the extent to which there is an imperfect understanding in the community of the positive joys of child bearing, rearing and caring. I think that there are very significant implications for Australia in that and I hope that we will see greater emphasis on a more pro-family policy approach from the Government in future.

TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL
This Bill contains a range of measures which have been the subject of announcements of changes to the income law by the Treasurer.
Three proposals included in the Bill are Budget initiatives.

They are the removal of the `negative gearing' limitation in relation to rental property investments, reduction in the rate of write-off for capital expenditure on new income producing buildings and income tax averaging arrangements for artists and sportspersons.
A number of provisions in the Bill are intended to deal with arrangements to exploit the operation of the income tax law.

The most significant measure in this area is the introduction of thin capitalisation rules to limit interest deductions of foreign investors in circumstances where their investments are highly geared.

Other `anti-avoidance' provisions deal with financial instruments in the nature of deferred annuities, discounted securities and similar instruments issued to non-resident associates and excessive private company dividends and non-arm's length income of approved deposit funds.

The Bill also includes measures relating to the supervision of occupational superannuation funds, facilitation of `shelf' companies, extensions of the investment allowance and gift provisions and a number of technical amendments.
Thin Capitalisation Measures

The Bill will introduce into the income tax law rules against thin capitalisation to prevent significant losses of revenue that can arise where foreign investors do not maintain an appropriate balance between debt and equity in respect of their income-producing activities in Australia.
The thin capitalisation rules contained in this Bill were foreshadowed by the Treasurer on 30 April 1987 and generally have effect from 1 July 1987.
They will replace administrative measures that had previously been imposed as a condition for approval of investments under foreign investment policy.

The proposals are directed at those foreign investments in Australia that are excessively geared up through the use of `in-house' loans, that is, loans made available by associated persons such as foreign parent companies and other related entities off-shore.

The measures will effectively impose statutory debt/equity ratios in relation to funding of foreign investments from non-arm's length sources where a non-resident has a 15 per cent or greater interest in an Australian entity or business.

Where foreign debt from such sources exceeds debt/equity ratios of six to one for financial institutions and three to one for other investors, deductions for interest payments will be reduced to the extent that the relevant ratio is exceeded.

While the amendments generally apply from 1 July 1987, under transitional measures borrowings that were approved under foreign investment policy and which exceed the new debt/equity ratios are to be freed from the new rules.
Transitional provisions are also to apply to companies engaged in mineral exploration.
Special provisions will also apply in the initial period of operation of the legislation in relation to the measurement of the level of foreign debt.

As the level of debt will generally be taken at its highest point during the year, affected taxpayers are being allowed until 30 November 1987 to make adjustments to their financial arrangements to ensure that their `in-house' debts comply with the applicable debt/equity ratio.

Asset revaluation reserves are to be taken into account in determining a company's equity for purposes of the debt/equity formula and will, in the first year of the new rules, be valued as at 28 October 1987, rather than at 1 July 1987, to ensure that foreign investors are not unduly disadvantaged by the new rules.
Associated measures, also announced on 30 April 1987, to counter tax avoidance arrangements arising out of certain kinds of corporate restructures, will be included in a later Bill.
Income Averaging for Artists and Sportspersons
The Bill will also introduce a new system of tax averaging for the specialist income of artists, composers, inventors, performers, production associates and writers.

This measure will give effect to the proposal announced by the Treasurer in the 1986-87 Budget to provide, with effect from the 1986-87 year of income, special arrangements designed to smooth out tax liabilities where fluctuating incomes would push such people into higher tax brackets.

The provisions of the income tax law which currently provide special treatment for the income of authors and inventors are to be repealed, although a taxpayer eligible to benefit from those provisions will be able to apply, in respect of the 1986-87 year of income only, for those provisions to apply in lieu of the new arrangements.
The estimated revenue cost of the new arrangements is $2m in 1987-88.
Negative Gearing

The Bill will also give effect to the 1987-88 Budget announcement that the income tax restriction on the deductibility of interest associated with the negative gearing of rental property investments is to be removed, with effect from the commencement of the 1987-88 income year.
Restoration of full tax deductibility of interest on rental property borrowings will mean uniformity of tax treatment of interest costs for all types of investment.

This measure has been made possible only as a result of the Government's comprehensive tax reform program-in particular, due to the implementation of a capital gains tax and the reduction of the top marginal tax rate to 49 per cent.

That reform program has brought a new integrity to the tax system and in so doing has relieved the tax paying community generally of the burden of the excessive tax benefits that negative gearing offered high income earners prior to July 1985 when the restriction now being lifted was introduced.
Deductions for Capital Expenditure on New Income-Producing Buildings
The Bill will also reduce the rate of annual deduction allowable for capital expenditure on the construction of new income-producing buildings, from 4 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent.
This reduction, which was announced in the 1987-88 Budget Speech, is complementary to the Government's restoration of full tax deductibility of interest on rental property borrowings.
The reduced rate of deduction will apply to new buildings, as well as to extensions, alterations or improvements to buildings, that commence to be constructed after 15 September 1987.

Special provisions will preserve the 4 per cent rate for buildings commenced after 15 September 1987 in any cases where the taxpayers who incur the capital expenditure had effectively committed themselves to the construction project on or before that date.

These changes are estimated to produce revenue savings of $3m in 1988-89, $10m in 1989-90, $29m in 1990-91 and $54m in 1991-92, continuing to rise significantly for many years and exceeding $500m per annum after 25 years.
Discounted and other Deferred Interest Securities

The Bill will also make changes first foreshadowed in an announcement of 19 September 1986 to ensure that the investment return under certain financial instruments which are in the nature of deferred annuities, and provide substantial tax deferral advantages, are taxed on an accruals basis rather than under concessional measures applicable to annuities generally.

Although the financial instruments in question are considered to fall within provisions that require the application of an accruals basis of taxation to discounted securities and certain other financial securities, amendments are to be made to remove doubts that have been expressed as to the operation of those provisions in their case.

The advantages of dressing up loan arrangements as annuities can be twofold-firstly, lower amounts of interest are assessed in earlier repayment years than would be the case if the money were lent by way of a loan with fixed equal repayment terms and, secondly, there can be a significant deferral of assessable income in the case of deferred annuities.

The amendments will ensure that the income element of affected annuities are taxed on an accruals basis and will apply respectively to relevant deferred annuities issued after 19 September 1986 and to immediate annuities issued or or after 29 October 1987.
A later application date is proposed for immediate annuities because the announcements of September 1986 were primarily concerned with the tax deferral advantages of deferred annuities.
The amendments will not affect the existing concessional tax treatment of traditional annuities such as those issued to individuals by life assurance companies.

The Bill will also modify the provisions that apply an accruals-based method of assessment of yields on discounted and certain other securities, to correct a feature that is capable of being exploited so as to give an unintended tax result.
This proposal was announced on 23 April 1987.

As long as an affected security is not issued off-shore nor made payable to bearer, the existing law entitles the issuer to deductions for payments of discount or other deferred interest payments on an accruals basis that generally parallels the basis upon which the holder of the security is taxed on those amounts.

Amendments in this Bill will preclude the allowance of deductions on an accruals basis where the security is issued in Australia after 23 April 1987 to or on behalf of a non-resident associate of the issuer.
That associate would typically bear tax only by way of interest withholding tax at redemption or prior transfer of the security on-shore.
The Bill also incorporates some minor technical adjustments to correct formula calculations for dealing with discounted securities and similar securities.
`Shelf' Companies
The Bill will also implement a change to a number of company grouping provisions of the income tax law to give effect to an announcement of 29 June 1987.

The purpose of these measures is to permit a newly incorporated company, commonly referred as a `shelf' company, to satisfy the 100 per cent common ownership test that is applied in various company grouping provisions of the law.

Those provisions permit transfers within company groups of deductions for company, losses, excess foreign tax credits, rental property interest and capital losses and for the roll-over of assets for the purpose of deferring liability for tax on capital gains.

The shelf companies affected by these amendments are ones introduced into a company group during an income year but which, although previously incorporated, had been dormant before their acquisition by the group.
The changes made by this Bill will apply to shelf companies first acquired by groups in the 1986-87 income year.
However, I would also draw to the attention of senators an announcement made by the Minister Assisting the Treasurer during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives.

In his announcement, the Minister foreshadowed that the Government has decided to accede to representations that the changes should apply from when each of the relevant grouping provisions was first made available.
The amendments to give effect to this decision will be included in a taxation Bill to be introduced later this sitting.

At the same time, the Government will also make other amendments to recognise that a change in the ownership of a shelf company may be affected by the issue of new shares from the shelf company to the purchaser in association with the redemption of the subscriber shares.
Investment Allowance

The Bill will give effect to the decision announced by the Treasurer on 12 June 1987 to extend by 6 months, from 1 July 1987 to 1 January 1988, the date by which eligible property must be used, or installed ready for use, if it is to qualify for the investment allowance.

The Government has decided to extend the investment allowance in the light of unavoidable delays that have occurred in the completion of some projects that in all other respects are eligible for the allowance.

In the absence of an amendment the delayed projects would have resulted in a windfall gain to revenue of an estimated $30m in 1987-88, with a corresponding loss of the same magnitude to the taxpayers involved.
Extension of the cut-off date will defer to the 1988-89 financial year the cash benefit to taxpayers and the cost to revenue.
Gifts

Amendments are also being made to the gift provisions of the income tax law to permit gifts to the Ninth Australian Division Memorial of Participation (Alamein) Fund and to the Korean and South East Asian and Vietnam War Memorials Anzac Square Trust Fund to attract deductions.
Gifts made to these two funds on or after 15 June 1987 and on or before 30 June 1989 will be deductible.

The estimated cost of admitting the Ninth Australian Division Memorial of Participation (Alamein) Fund is $100,000 in each of the years 1988-89 and 1989-90 and that for the South East Asian and Vietnam War Memorials Anzac Square Trust Fund is $50,000 in each of those years.
Approved Deposit Funds
The Bill also introduces measures announced on 12 January 1987 to tax excessive private company dividends and non-arm's length income of approved deposit funds.

The amendment will ensure that approved deposit funds do not abuse the tax-free status they were given when established as part of the Government's 1984 tax package for lump sum superannuation and other retirement payments.
Income affected by this measure will be taxed at the rate of 50 per cent for the 1986-87 income year and 49 per cent for later years.
Occupational Superannuation

Also contained in this Bill are measures to effect the handover to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of responsibility for supervision of certain aspects of the activities of superannuation funds and approved deposit funds currently undertaken by the Commissioner of Taxation.

As foreshadowed in the second reading speech on the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill earlier in these sittings, these amendments are part of the legislative package necessary to establish the new supervisory arrangements for superannuation funds.

Superannuation funds and approved deposit funds which comply with operating standards and other relevant conditions administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner will continue to be exempt from tax on their investment income.

The Commissioner of Taxation will retain responsibility for the assessment of tax on income of non-complying funds, certain private company dividends and excessive non-arm's length income derived by funds and where any excessive or unauthorised benefits are paid from funds.
The Commissioner of Taxation will also retain responsibility for allowing income tax deductions for contributions made to superannuation funds.

To facilitate these changes, the Bill will also amend the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 to remedy certain technical and drafting defects as well as enabling a de facto spouse of a member of a superannuation fund to receive benefits from the fund in the event of the member's death.

Amendments of the Taxation Administration Act will permit the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to utilise the prosecution provisions of the income tax law against fund trustees who breach requirements in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act relating to the provision of information and documents.
The amendments proposed to the occupational superannuation provisions of the income tax law are not expected to have any significant effect on revenue.

The Government has also decided that, in view of the substantial increase in recent years in the number of superannuation funds and employees covered by funds and the possible significant revenue implications arising as a result of any across-the-board increases in the level of maximum permissible benefits, responsibility for fixing superannuation reasonable benefit limits will be transferred to the government of the day.

This change will allow the Government to determine the reasonable benefit limits in the light of its budgetary and other priorities and is consistent with its policy of subjecting tax expenditures to greater scrutiny.
An explanatory memorandum which comprehensively explains the measures contained in this Bill is being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FRINGE BENEFITS AND SUBSTANTIATION) BILL 1987
This Bill will amend the fringe benefits tax and income tax laws.
It will implement a large number of fringe benefits tax changes of a concessional kind that were announced by the Treasurer on 26 August and 29 October 1986.

It also contains income tax amendments announced on 29 October 1986 to exclude from substantiation claims against travel allowances paid under award conditions where the amount of the allowance is not greater than was payable under the award on that date.
When introducing the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill last year, the Treasurer described it as a major part of the Government's tax reform program.

He did so against the background that for some years the income tax law had been increasingly exploited by predominantly higher income taxpayers converting substantial parts of their remuneration into non-taxed fringe benefits.
That course had been open to them because there were technical deficiencies in the income tax law itself and because previous governments had displayed little enthusiasm to remedy them.
This Government had no such hesitation.
The fringe benefits tax legislation, therefore, was a very important measure both in its content and its contribution to restoring public confidence in the equity of the Australian tax system.
Like other tax reform measures, it has been more successful than we anticipated.
At the time of its introduction, the revenue gain from the imposition of fringe benefits tax was estimated at $300m in 1986-87 and $540m in 1987-88.
However, excluding payments by Commonwealth Government departments, actual revenue collections for 1986-87 were $535m, some $200m more than originally estimated.
The estimated receipts for 1987-88 are $750m.
These results demonstrate forcefully the merit of the Government's actions to correct the costly inequities that had arisen from the growing use of fringe benefit packages.

The measures contained in the Bill reflect a response by the Government to community concerns that the car log book and certain other record keeping obligations contained in the original legislation were overly burdensome, that some benefits-particularly those of a minor or compassionate kind-which were technically taxable should have been exempt, and that a greater degree of discounting was warranted in taxing remote area housing and other remote area benefits.

I emphasise that while the Government has shown its willingness to respond to reasonable community representations on the operation of the fringe benefits tax law, it has not and will not yield to pressures to alter the basic structure and principles of the tax.

The general effects of the amendments being made by the Bill were set out in the two announcements mentioned earlier, and I do not propose to take up the time of the chamber in discussing them in detail at this time.
In giving effect to the announced measures it has been necessary to modify the operation of one of the proposals.

On 29 October last year it was announced that the general rule for determining the reduction in taxable value arising from employee contributions was to be changed so that any contribution by an employee was first set off against the private component of the benefit.
While that will continue to be the general rule in practice, its operation could have produced inequitable results in cases where the contribution was not in fact related to the private component.

As explained in the explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill, the reduction rule now being introduced will apply flexibly to reflect the particular circumstances under which employee contributions are made.

A further reduction rule applies under the law to ensure that employee expenses borne by the employer are not subject to fringe benefits tax where the expenses would otherwise have been deductible for income tax purposes in the hands of the employee.
Presently, expenditure of a kind that would otherwise be subject to the negative gearing rules is excluded from this `otherwise deductible' rule.

Consistent with the Government's decision to remove the negative gearing rules for income tax purposes with effect from the 1987-88 income tax year, the exclusion will cease to apply for fringe benefits tax purposes with effect from the 1987-88 fringe benefits tax year, which commenced on 1 April 1987.
Before concluding I draw attention to two proposed changes to the fringe benefits tax law that have not been possible to include in this Bill due to time constraints.

In his announcement of 29 October 1986, the Treasurer said that the fringe benefits tax liability arising from any discounts of purchase price under home ownership schemes in remote areas was to be amortised over the period, if any, of the relevant purchase contract until unrestricted title passes to the employee.
These rather complex proposals have been the subject of lengthy discussions between officials of the Treasurer's Department and representatives of the Australian mining industry.
While it will not now be possible to bring the amendments forward until the autumn sittings of the Parliament the industry has been advised in detail of the arrangements that will apply.
The second matter arises from discussion in the tax liaison group.

As noted in the 29 October 1986 announcement the liaison group, which was established in 1984 by the Commissioner of Taxation with the major legal and accounting bodies, was to be used as a forum for further consultations with tax practitioners on technical and practical aspects of the tax reform package.

The Government has decided to accept the proposal emanating from that group to introduce amendments that will facilitate genuine arrangements under which employers may be reimbursed by employees for the whole or a part of the fringe benefits tax liability attributable to the employee's benefit, or from a third party such as a manufacturer who arranges incentives for employees of a retailer.
These amendments will be introduced in the autumn sittings of Parliament next year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

As honourable senators will see the Bill is a lengthy one reflecting the number of concessions granted and the structural features of the existing law that have made it necessary, at a technical level, to repeat a number of the revised reduction rules.
Nevertheless, the details of the changes are, as explained in the explanatory memorandum, relatively straightforward.
SALES TAX (OFF-SHORE INSTALLATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

This Bill is part of a package of sea installations Bills which will extend the application of Australian laws regulating customs, migration, quarantine and taxation to installations in Australia's off-shore waters.
The measures proposed by this bill are two-fold.

First, the Bill will extend the coverage of the sales tax law to areas within 200 nautical miles of the Territorial limits of Australia, the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands, and the Coral Sea island territories-in some areas this will extend beyond the present boundary of the outer limits of the continental shelf.

The reach of the existing sales tax law does not generally extend outside geographical Australia, although since 1982 it has had a limited application within the Australian continental shelf area in relation to installations attached to the seabed for the purposes of exploring for or exploiting natural resources.
The second measure contained in the Bill expands the types of off-shore installations which will be subject to Australian sales tax law when installed in these areas.
Broadly, this is when they are either attached to the seabed or are in these areas for a specified duration.

The amendments will apply to off-shore installations that are located in Australian waters for a number of specified purposes, including tourism, recreation, business activities, marine archaeology, fishing, scientific activity or transport activity. The effect will be that any installation used for the purposes of any of these prescribed activities will take on the status of a place in Australia from the date of its installation in Australian waters.

As a consequence, any transaction or act affecting goods on such an installation which would be taxable if the goods were in geographical Australia will be taxable as if those goods were in Australia.

In addition, any installation which is brought from overseas to be installed in Australian waters, and any goods on it at the time it is brought in, will be deemed to be imported into Australia and on that basis, will be subject to the sales tax law in respect of that importation.

The amendments made by this Bill will, in relation to installations that are attached to the seabed in Australian waters, operate with effect from 21 January 1987, the date these measures were announced by the Treasurer.
In the case of other installations, the Bill will apply on and after 29 October 1987.
The revenue impact of the measures proposed by this Bill will depend on the development of such installations in our off-shore areas and so cannot be determined at this time.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, which is now before the Senate, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987-the harmonised tariff-which was passed by Parliament in the Autumn sittings.

The international convention on which the harmonised tariff is based will come into force on 1 January 1988. It is the Government's intention that the new tariff as amended by this Bill will operate from the same date. These amendments, which are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum presented with the Bill, can be divided into three main categories-

First, those required to implement decisions on industry assistance and trade relations matters taken since the close-off date for the principal legislation-many reflect changes already implemented in the current tariff;
Second, amendments to correct anomalies created by the translation of current assistance arrangements to the harmonised format; and
Third, editorial amendments to clarify the intention of the convention and to correct errors in the original legislation.

The first group of amendments results from Government decisions on the development of the pharmaceutical products industry and the chemicals and plastics industries, and those taken following receipt of industries Assistance Commission (IAC) reports on-
vegetables and vegetable products;
luggage, handbags and similar containers; and
reconditioned automotive engines.
With the exception of pharmaceutical products and reconditioned engines, the amendments implement, in the harmonised tariff, changes which have already been commenced in the current tariff.

Amendments following the Government's consideration of the pharmaceutical products industry and the IAC report on reconditioned automotive engines are consistent with the Government's policy to encourage internationally competitive industries and to reduce reliance on tariff assistance. The amendments reduce the general tariff rate on glycosides from the current 20 per cent to 2 per cent, crepe bandages from 20 per cent to 5 per cent, wadding from 20 per cent to 10 per cent and certain automotive engines from 25 per cent to 15 per cent. Also falling to this category are amendments implementing the Government's continuing sectoral policies in respect of textiles, clothing and footwear and passenger motor vehicles.

The second group consists of amendments to redress assistance anomalies which have become apparent following publication of the harmonised tariff. In its report on tariff harmonisation, the IAC calculated its recommended option two would have little effect on industry assistance generally. However, it conceded that duty rates for particular goods might vary significantly. Eight anomalies have been brought to notice which would have unacceptable consequences for the industries concerned.
These, and the remedial actions proposed, are:
chain of precious metal-duties are increased from 2 per cent to 25 per cent to maintain the current assistance level
solar cells and assembled solar arrays-duties are increased from 2 per cent to 20 per cent to maintain current assistance levels
beverage concentrates-duties are decreased from 10 per cent to 5 per cent to maintain the current duty rate
wadding of textiles materials-duties are decreased from 25 per cent to the current rate of 2 per cent

certain air compressors-these goods are currently under reference to the IAC. Pending the outcome of this review, duties have been increased from 5 per cent to 15 or 25 per cent. The amendment reflects the more detailed structures proposed by the IAC in option one of its recommendations on the harmonised tariff
motorcycle exhaust systems-duties are increased from 5 per cent to 20 per cent to maintain current assistance levels
certain commercial cooking equipment-duties are decreased from 25 per cent to 15 per cent to maintain the current duty rate
ammunition-duties are increased from 10 or 15 per cent to 20 per cent to more accurately reflect current arrangements

Finally, the third group of amendments includes minor redrafting and additional notes to some sections and chapters to clarify the intent of the convention, to correct errors and to strengthen some provisions in the Principal Act.
The opportunity has also been taken to remove a redundant item in Schedule 4 to the Principal Act.
Financial Impact
The decreases in customs duty rates for the pharmaceutical products will result in an estimated decrease in revenue of $568,000 during the financial year 1987-88.

The vegetables and vegetable products industry has undergone considerable rationalisation in recent times, particularly in the processing sector. It is expected that there will be further rationalisation in the tomato growing and processing sector. The changes to rates of duty are expected to have minimal financial impact.

It is difficult to quantify the financial consequences of the decision on the chemicals and plastics industries. However, it is likely that the removal of the concessional arrangements will provide some increase in duty payments. In the context of the Government's overall decision on chemicals and plastics which considerably reduced tariff rates, the net effect of the current changes will be minimal.

The impact of the change to flax yarns is also difficult to isolate from changes associated with a move to a uniform 15 per cent duty rate for yarns and threads not subject to bounty. In the financial year 1987-88 the changes affecting flax yarns are likely to add approximately $200,000 to revenue and $400,000 in a full year. This is based on annual imports in recent years averaging around $8m from those sources affected by the 5 per cent increase in duties. The remainder of the changes to textiles, clothing and footwear are expected to have no financial impact.
It is expected that the changes to duty applying to ammunition could lead to a small net increase in revenue.

The reduction in duty on off-road vehicles from an average rate of 63 per cent to 25 per cent is expected to reduce revenue by up to $400,000 in a full year. This loss to the revenue could be offset by additional customs duty through increased imports as the lower duty rate plus removal of quota restrictions increases demand.
The imposition of a surcharge of 3.9c per litre on aviation gasoline will raise an estimated $3.9m in the financial year 1987-88.
There is expected to be minimal financial impact caused by the other amendments in the Bill.
Details of the amendments contained in the Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill.
CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to amend the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act 1975 to ensure that certain exports of coal to steaming coal markets, at the lower prices operating in those markets, do not attract the coal export duty, which is currently set at $3.50 a tonne.

The coal export duty was introduced in August 1975, at a time of high industry profitability as a way of distributing to the wider community windfall profits accruing to coal exporting companies. Over the years, the duty has been modified to recognise changed economic circumstances in the industry.

The present policy objective of the Act is to make dutiable only high quality coking coal destined for world steel industry markets. These coals attract a price premium relative to steaming coal, which is exempt from export duty.

As a result of changing demand in the international market place, some Australian mines producing coking grade coal are presently unable to sell all their production into coking coal markets, but they are able to sell a less highly refined or washed version of the coal into steaming coal markets at the lower prices applying for this product. However, the existing parameters defining the characteristics of the coal on which duty under the Act is based is having the unintended effect of rendering this lower quality product liable for duty.

In view of this, the Government has decided to change the parameters on which the duty is based by reducing the prescribed ash content of the coals from 12 per cent or less to 10.5 per cent or less and raising the crucible swelling number (a measure of the coal's coking characteristic) from over 3 to over 5. These changes will ensure that the policy objective of the Act, which is to only make high quality coking coal subject to duty, is continued.
Financial Impact
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications, as the Bill seeks to continue existing coal export duty arrangements in operation since 16 May 1987.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend several sections of the Wheat Marketing Act 1984 to implement, in relation to the Australian Wheat Board, certain provisions of the Government's policy on the reform of statutory marketing authorities and to incorporate in the Act provisions consistent with the Government's policy on equal employment opportunity.

The majority of the Government's proposals outlined in the White Paper `Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities', which was released in January 1986, were incorporated in an amendment to the wheat marketing legislation last year. One area of that policy which was not fully addressed at that time was the funding of industry organisations by the Board. The Governments position is that where there is a requirement for consultation between a statutory marketing authority and its industry, decisions on payments to the industry for those consultations should be left to the Authority concerned. However, because the funds of statutory marketing authorities are derived from either grower levies or from the sale of a compulsory-acquired product, it has been considered desirable that guidelines be issued to ensure that any monies paid to industry organisation will be for consultations consistent with the statutory objectives and functions of the Authority. In particular, such monies should not be available for agro-political purposes. The Bill provides for the issue of such guidelines to the Board and subject to those guidelines for it to meet expenses additional to travel incurred by the Grains Council of Australia in relation to consultation with the Board. The Board is already accountable to growers through a statutory requirement for members to consult at least annually with the Grains Council to present the Board's annual report.

The proposed guidelines would restrict the level of funding to 50 per cent of the Grains Council's operational expenditure in any one year. Details will need to be included in the Board's Annual Operational Plan and financial statements. The Board will also be able, if it wishes, to meet the travel expenses only of any person or body with whom it consults for the purpose of carrying out its functions.

The Bill provides that the composition of the Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee will be consistent with the policy in the White Paper that such committees comprise only an independent Chairperson and representatives of the relevant industry who have been nominated by the nationally recognised industry body. The current provisions of the Act, which were put in place prior to the development of that policy, allow for the Chairman of the Board and two representatives of the National Farmers Federation to also be members of the Committee. This approach was adopted in the belief that a broad-based Committee would be better able to select the most capable and effective persons to be members of the Board. While that Committee fulfilled its responsibilities in a highly satisfactory manner, it is nevertheless considered desirable that the situation for the Board should be consistent with the Guidelines established in the White Paper on Statutory Marketing Authorities, that those who finance an Authority should be represented on the Committee which determines who will be recommended to the Minister for appointment. To further ensure the objectivity of the selection process, it is essential that membership of the Committee is independent from the membership of the Board.

It is therefore proposed that the representatives of the National Farmers Federation and the Chairman of the Board will no longer be members of the Committee. The National Farmers Federation and the Grains Council are agreeable to this change.

Should it be considered desirable for the Chairperson of the AWB to continue to be consulted in order for the Committee to have a better understanding of the qualities necessary for a person to be an effective Board member, then such a requirement could be incorporated in the selection criteria issued to the Committee or in the terms and conditions of appointment of the Presiding Member.

Finally the Bill provides for the Board to develop and implement an equal employment opportunity program which is consistent with the Government's policies being progressively introduced for other Commonwealth authorities. Details of such programs will need to be included in the Board's Corporate and Annual Operational Plans and in its Annual Report to Parliament. I would point out that the Board already has recognised the need to be a progressive employer and has reflected this in its Corporate objectives. Part of its strategies to meet this objective is the development and implementation of an equal employment opportunity program. The proposed amendments should not involve any additional Commonwealth costs or revenue. They are being put forward as part of the program of implementing the reform of statutory marketing authorities. The benefits of these reforms are already evident in the operations of other major authorities. I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

The speech read as follows-

This Bill contains amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and minor amendments to several other Acts to implement decisions announced in the May Economic Statement and the 1987/88 Budget Speech.
This Bill provides for the introduction of the family package which was announced earlier this year as a Labor Government election commitment.

The family package is the centrepiece of this Government's attack on child poverty-not only for families where parents depend on social security because they are sick or unemployed-but for working families who have carried the burden of economic adjustment over the past few years.

The family package is based on the basic principle that every Australian child has the right to an adequate standard of living-it is also based on the solid Labor tradition of help for people in need of support.
It was the Lang Labor Government which introduced the world's first child endowment-to recognise the extra costs of families with children.
The Curtin Labor Government gave child endowment a new priority by increasing payments and extending them to Aboriginal communities and to people with the custody of orphans.
The Whitlam Labor Government introduced the handicapped child's allowance to provide extra support to families with handicapped children.
The Hawke Government's family package will build on this record to deliver substantial increases in public support for children.
It includes the family allowance supplement-a new payment which aims to help families on low wages meet the day to day expenses of bringing up children.

Subject to an income test, Family Allowance Supplement of $22 a week will be paid for each child under the age of 13, and $28 a week will be paid for 13-, 14-and 15-year-olds in recognition of the extra costs associated with teenage children.
Family allowance supplement replaces the family income supplement which paid $17 a week for each child in working families according to a more stringent income test.

In order to make the family allowance supplement an enduring reform, the Government is committed to increase the payment in real terms over the next two years. We will index the payment in the same way we index pensions.

In this financial year we estimate that around one million children will enjoy a better standard of living from the tax-free benefits of this package-440,000 children are in working families, another 740,000 children are from out of work families.
Child payments for families which depend on income support from social security will be increased automatically in December from $17 a week to the new levels under the family package.

This Labor Government has been steadily increasing payments for children in the social security system-in fact the family allowance supplement will be the fifth pay increase for the poorest children in our community since 1983.
The rate increases in this Bill are by far the most significant to date.

In total there has been a 120 per cent increase in additional pension and benefit (the child payments for families on social security) for children aged under 13, and a massive 180 per cent increase for young teenagers over the rates payable under the Fraser Government.
There are two additional parts to the family package.

The family package will extend rent assistance of up to $15 a week for low income working families in privately rented homes-this is the first time that rental assistance has been offered to help working families with their housing costs.
Families on unemployment and sickness benefit will no longer have to serve a separate waiting period for rent assistance, and will get their help for housing from their first benefit payment.
The package also contains more money for disabled children-with the introduction of the new child disability allowance paid at $112 a month per child to all families with disabled children.
The child disability allowance will be income-test free and up to 10,000 additional children are expected to qualify for the payment.

The 27,000 severely disabled children currently getting the handicapped child's allowance will be automatically transferred to the new payment-and their allowance will be increased from $92 to $112 a month.
Another 5,000 marginally less disabled children will have the income test on their payments removed and will also receive more money under the family package.

The Department of Social Security is to start a major consultation on eligibility criteria for the child disability allowance to make sure that the right children get the right money at the right time.
The measures outlined in this Bill demonstrate this Government's firm commitment to ensure that no Australian child need live in poverty by 1990.
The package takes the first step towards constructing a new system of public support for children which stresses the need for adequate payments-targeted to those families which need help the most.
This Bill represents substantial gains for our most disadvantaged families which have suffered from the impact of sickness or unemployment.

It also highlights the need to support working families bringing up children on low incomes. The family allowance supplement is designed to allow income to increase by 25 per cent over any four-week period without affecting payments-this is to accommodate pay fluctuations such as overtime.

The structure of this historically important payment aims to encourage people to stay in the work force, where there is potential for them to build a decent standard of living on the basis of an independent wage.
The family package will increase the disposable incomes of working families-making them much better off than comparable families living on unemployment benefit.
This emphasis on labour market participation in the structure of social security benefits is reflected by changes contained in this Bill in the area of income support for young people.

The job search allowance will replace unemployment benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds in January-it will make it very clear that income support is closely tied to the need for young people to be better prepared for the work force.

The Commonwealth Employment Service will maintain close contact with young people on the job search allowance-and where those young people need extra help to find a job, they can be enrolled in vocational training courses, or instructed in job searching skills.
We cannot let our young people waste their potential-and the job search allowance aims to give them a helping hand in constructive ways.
Job search allowance, sickness benefit and special benefit for people under 18 will, in most cases, be subject to a parental income test similar to the one which applies to Austudy payments.

Job search allowance will be paid at $50 a week, subject to a parental income test-but this test will not reduce the payment below $25 a week. Job search allowance will, of course, be subject to an income test on the young person's own income.

An assets test is being introduced on the payment of unemployment, sickness and special benefit to people who are aged 25 and over. Under the assets test, benefit will generally not be paid to people whose assets exceed a specified amount. These amounts are the same as those used for the pension assets test.
The Government expects to save some $24.5m in 1988-89 through the introduction of this initiative.

The age of 25 years for the benefits assets test has been included because available information indicates that very few young people below that age would be disqualified by the assets test. Not to include that age threshold would add greatly to administrative costs and effort for very little return.
People in financial hardship and not eligible to apply for other forms of Commonwealth income support may receive benefit under the hardship provisions.

Under the hardship provisions of the assets test, certain assets can be disregarded. However, income which could reasonably be generated by those disregarded assets is taken into account when calculating the rate of pension payable under the hardship provisions.
Recent interpretations of this provision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have undermined its purpose and effect so this Bill contains a measure to clarify the Government's intention.
Pension calculated under the financial hardship test will be reduced by the greater of-
2.5 per cent per annum of the property disregarded under the test; or
the income which could reasonably be expected to be obtained from commercial use of the property disregarded under the test.

The assets test will also be amended to ensure that the deprivation provisions will apply in situations where the person ceases work and disposes of property at the same time. This is to reverse the effect of a recent Federal Court decision.

The Bill before us contains measures to clarify the treatment of income from investments and to ensure that people with deferred income including income from friendly society bonds are not disadvantaged over pensioners and beneficiaries with more straightforward forms of income such as that deriving from bank deposits.

Depending on the type of investment involved, income will either be assessed on a regular basis throughout the term or, as in the case of market-linked investments, be averaged out over the 12 months after the person realises a profit on the investment.
The income from deferred income investments which were obtained before 1 January 1988 will continue to be assessed when it is realised.

Double orphans' pension of $60 per month will be extended to children who have one deceased parent and whose surviving parent is a nursing home patient for an indefinite period. The Government considers that the guardians of these children are as deserving of financial assistance as those children whose surviving parent is receiving treatment in a mental hospital for an indefinite period.
Several changes which will assist pensioners are being introduced in this Bill.

The pensioner earnings credit will encourage pensioners and supporting parents to obtain short term work without reduction in pension. It will help pensioners, particularly sole parents, make the transition between relying on social security payments and being financially independent through employment.

Eligibility for carer's pension will be extended to people who are caring for an age or invalid pensioner at home but who are not close relatives. This is a compassionate measure to assist friends to provide care in a home environment for those who are unable to look after themselves.

The fringe benefit rules are being changed so that persons whose incomes go above the income limits can retain entitlement to fringe benefits for up to three months, provided their incomes do not go over 125 per cent of their limit.

This measure will be of particular assistance to pensioners who obtain part time employment or receive other income which is indexed by CPI changes and to those receiving overseas payments who have in the past sometimes lost fringe benefits because their income has been affected by fluctuations in exchange rates.

The Bill before us graphically demonstrates this Government's continuing concern for those in our society most in need of support. It provides for significant additional payments to families on modest incomes and for increases in additional payments for children made to pensioners and beneficiaries.

The Bill contains measures such as the assets test on benefits and the parental income test for job search allowance which will reduce expenditure currently being paid to those who are able to provide for themselves and their families and enable resources to be directed to those in greatest need.
The Bill will also make a number of amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Legislation.

Some of these amendments reflect those which I have already outlined for social security legislation. This will ensure consistency in the treatment of service pensioners and Social Security pensioners in the following areas:
modification of the definition of `income' that is used for the purpose of assessing the rate of service pension payable;
amendments to the assets test provisions;
easing of the application of the fringe benefits test, and
enabling service pensioners to take advantage of earnings credit arrangements.

The Bill also gives legislative effect to the Government's major decision not to allow the adverse interpretations given in three recent Federal Court decisions to the provisions of the Veteran's Entitlement Act relating to eligibility for the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) rate and intermediate rate of pension to stand.

The Federal Court took the view that the eligibility criteria must be met by a veteran on a continuing basis and that such a pension was not payable after attaining normal retiring age or indefinitely.

In order to overcome this interpretation, the Bill provides two related changes. The first will ensure that initial eligibility for the grant of TPI or intermediate rate pension is not to be determined on a continuing basis.
Eligibility is to be determined by reference to whether a veteran meets the requirements of section 23 or 24 on the date of lodgment of a pension claim or application.

The amendment will prevent account being taken of alterations in the veterans' circumstances, subsequent to lodging the claim or application, which might adversely affect eligibility. This will avoid the possibility of a grant of TPI or intermediate rate pension that is made being limited by the determining body to a specified period, up to say retirement age, as was adverted to by the Federal Court in the McGuire case.

The second change is to insert a new section 24a in the Veterans' Entitlements Act. This will ensure that persons who are eligible to receive and are receiving a TPI or intermediate rate pension will not ordinarily lose payment of pension at such a rate in their lifetime.

The only exceptions are where the grant of pension would not have been made but for a false statement or misrepresentation or where the veteran's war-caused incapacity improves to the extent that he or she is undertaking, or becomes capable of undertaking, remunerative work for periods greater than specified in the existing law.

The amendments to be made in respect of TPI and intermediate rate pension do not otherwise affect the changes of eligibility for these pensions made by the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Act 1985 and carried through in the Veterans' Entitlements Act and the interpretations given to the relevant provisions by the courts; nor do the amendments affect the powers of the Veterans' Review Board or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to review whether the initial grant of TPI or intermediate rate pension was made properly.

Another important change is that, in accordance with the Government's electoral undertaking, the Bill will extend eligibility for full hospital and medical treatment to returned ex-servicewomen of World War 2. This recognises the valuable contribution made by such women in the defence of this nation during that war.

Other amendments proposed to be made to veterans' affairs legislation provide for increases in the rates of the minor benefits available to eligible persons and increases in the rates of clothing allowance, attendant allowance and recreation transport allowance.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the estimates of expenditure for the Department of Industrial Relations. When the committee debate was commenced on Friday last, Senator Michael Baume made several very pertinent comments about these estimates. Today I would like to follow on some of Senator Michael Baume's comments. I thank him for the opportunity to do this by virtue of the fact that he spoke in my place on Friday due to my unexpected absence. Therefore, he has provided me with an opportunity to make a few remarks today. I thank Senator Michael Baume for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The points I wish to raise in the estimates of the Department of Industrial Relations relate essentially to the grants by the Department to the trade union movement. In the replies to questions that I asked of the Department of Industrial Relations a whole series of grants made to trade unions by the Department are listed. I regret that the information which we requested in advance was not available by the time Estimates Committee A actually met to consider these estimates and therefore members of the Committee were not able to question the departmental officials about the grants. That is a matter of regret. It is not a matter that is peculiar to the Department of Industrial Relations. Indeed, one of the worrying features about Estimates committee hearings is that all too often the information sought in advance by senators from departments is not available at the time of the hearing and therefore the information, whilst no doubt useful in due course, loses much of its significance if it is not available in time for it to be discussed with the officials in committee. As I have said, that complaint is common to virtually all departments and all Estimates committees.

I would like to draw to the attention of the chamber some of the grants that are shown in the material that has now been received from the Department of Industrial Relations. They are shown in appendix 1 of some additional information that was received by Estimates Committee A. This document has been circulated to all honourable senators. I asked the Department: `Which grants, if any, have been made or approved since the May 1987 Senate estimates?'. So we were looking to any trade unions or community groups in 1986-87 and so far this financial year. The information contained in the response to that question really relates only to information available since May 1987-a very short period of months.

We find in that information another long list of grants that have been made to trade unions by the Department of Industrial Relations for a variety of purposes. For example, the Trades Hall Council of Victoria received another $35,000 from the Department for the employment of an industrial democracy officer to provide co-ordination and support to Trades Hall Council affiliates involved in industrial democracy initiatives; $45,000 was granted to the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia in Sydney, again for an industrial democracy officer; $35,000 went to the Joint Union Advisory Committee of the State Energy Commission of Western Australia. I might add that that $35,000 goes along with a payment by the State Energy Commission of Western Australia-a government agency-of approximately $200,000 to support the activity of the Joint Union Advisory Committee in 1987-88. So what we are looking at there in terms of taxpayers' money going to the union is not $35,000 but $235,000. There was a payment of an additional $35,000 to the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council, again for the employment of an industrial democracy officer; the Trade Union Community Research Centre of Tasmania received $40,000 for the employment of project officers to continue to provide industrial democracy and so on; and $37,000 went to the Australian national office of the Building Workers Industrial Union, again for the employment of an industrial democracy officer.

At the time I sought that information I also asked what contribution, if any, would be made by the trade unions towards the projects for which they had received funds. The information which has been provided is very sketchy indeed. Basically, what it adds up to is that the unions themselves, the recipients of these grants, with a couple of notable exceptions, are not required to contribute heavily to the overall cost themselves. It certainly does not appear to be a condition precedent that they do so at all. I think that is a matter of great concern.

Those grants that I have just mentioned are really simply the tip of the iceberg. As I have said, they follow grants that have been made by the Department over many years prior to May 1987. Basically, these are just supplementary figures. But a more disturbing fact is that they do not include payments of literally millions of dollars by this Government to trade unions in a whole variety of ways since it came into office. Last year I was a member of the Waste Watch Committee under Senator Michael Baume's very capable leadership and we investigated in great detail payments that had been made, particularly via the Australia Council, through the arts in working life program and the like, to trade unions with very little screening of those payments in terms of their merit--

TALK.START.PARA: —And millions of dollars.

—As Senator Baume has said quite rightly, it runs into millions of dollars. In fact, under that program alone-I do not have the figures in front of me-from memory I think that, over the last three years, for the arts in working life program alone the figure well exceeded $3m.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that the Opposition makes is not, as has sometimes been said, that the Opposition is against the trade union movement, for example, being involved in providing art, recreational and cultural activities for its members. That is not the point at issue. The point at issue is whether taxpayers' money should be used to fund those activities. I think the evidence is that the overwhelming majority of Australians-including, I would guess, many trade union members themselves-would see that as an inappropriate use of taxpayers' money. There are some very considerable problems about it. It appears to entrench trade union privilege in a society which is becoming increasingly sceptical and concerned about the growing use and abuse of trade union power. It also provides, for a Labor government in office, a fundamental conflict of interest for the Government because the trade union movement is simply the industrial wing of the Australian Labor Party and the parliamentary Labor Party is the political wing of the labour movement.

So we have a considerable conflict of interest so far as the Government is concerned. I think what many Australians, and certainly what most taxpayers, are asking is: Why on earth is this Labor Government shelling out countless millions of dollars to its own industrial wing? There can be only one answer to that question; that is, that the trade union movement is receiving privileged treatment because, in effect, it is part of the Labor Government. I think that is a matter of great national concern and is a national scandal. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, was waxing eloquent, before his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) chopped him off at the knees a couple of months ago, about the number of programs that the Government should cut if it were fair dinkum about trying to get its expenditure and the economy under control. Senator Walsh said that 200 programs should be cut. He took me up on the point that he was not talking about social welfare programs-which he was. He did not answer my retort adequately. I would be interested to know whether the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, would regard any of these programs and expenditures by the Department of Industrial Relations to trade unions, and other avenues of expenditure by the Government to trade unions, as amongst those programs which should be cut. I very much think he would.

There is another aspect in relation to trade unions and their role and position in society that is not generally known but should also be of very considerable concern. That is the treatment under the Income Tax Assessment Act of the income of trade unions. I wonder how many people know that section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act says:
The following income shall be exempt from income tax . . .
One of those things is contained in section 23 (f):

The income of a trade union and the income of an association of employers or employees registered under any Act or State Act, or under any law enforced in a Territory being part of Australia relating to the settlement of industrial disputes.

In other words, under this provision, no income of any trade union may be subject to tax levied under the Income Tax Assessment Act. That is also a matter of very great concern. That change in the Act was made after this Government came to office. Admittedly, it also applies to employer organisations but the income of employer organisations is a mere tittle compared with the enormous and increasingly growing income of the trade union movement.

We on this side of politics are certainly looking very seriously at that provision in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Quite frankly, I think it is a nonsense and is another example of the trade union movement being placed in a very privileged position. Many things can be said about the estimates of the Department of Industrial Relations. The comments I have made in relation to trade union privileges and the placing by this Government of trade unions in a privileged position compared with any other group in our society concern the points I find to be amongst the most obnoxious in the considerations of this Department. They should be of the greatest concern to the taxpayer and public. Certainly this is a matter of the greatest concern to the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. I say that, in no way being against the trade union movement per se. It is not a matter of opposing the existence or role of trade unions. They have a very legitimate role in our society. That is accepted universally, but what is not acceptable is the privileged position in which they are put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) has raised the question of whether the art in working life program was an appropriate way of spending government money. He says that bringing art to the people is such a worthwhile venture that this particular method is justified. I want to respond to that by stating that our opposition to that program has nothing to do with whether or not arts should be brought to the people. The Opposition, by its actions when in government, demonstrated that it was in favour of bringing art to the people-because it began that program; our Government funded it. But it did not fund it in such a way that the unions took it over.

SPEECH.PARA: There is evidence available in the printed material to show that that program has now been used as a way of moulding the arts to become a weapon in the industrial relations battle. It is clearly shown-and I quoted this in the Senate last year, and the Minister should be interested in this-that artists were told that they would not be given grants, if they wanted this grant money obtained under the arts in working life program, to be used in abstract for artistic purposes. They were told this money would be available and that they need apply for it only if they were going to use it the way the unions directed-for the best interests of the unions, not those of arts in the community, or to bring art to the people. This is the whole issue. For this Minister to be incapable of understanding that, or deliberately distorting our objection, shows either an inability to grasp reality or a determination to distort it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only since he has been a Minister that anybody has brought art to him.

—That is an acceptable point but I would not have thought that the words `working life' would have been appropriate in his case. The reality is that this program, funded and supported by the Liberal and National parties when in government, has been distorted and corrupted by this Government in order to pay off sections of the union movement which have been disenchanted by this Government and which have been enraged by its failure to deliver on what they expected and to stand by its platform on almost every issue one can name. The unions have been bought off. This is one of the methods. Some of the grants under the present arrangement that Senator Short was just dealing with are part of a pattern of buying off dissident elements of the industrial wing of the labour movement by the political wing of the labour movement, which has not delivered as requested.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say, quite frankly, that I am glad that in many areas this Government has not delivered according to its platform. I am glad that in some areas at least it has recognised what we have been saying for so long and has adopted some of our policies. It has adopted them incompetently, partially and without acknowledgment but at least, particularly in its moves into deregulation, it has accepted at last many of the principles which we established and which it violently opposed in opposition. The two-faced Minister opposite who now seeks to take credit for the things he and his Party opposed violently in opposition is a walking example of the sort of hypocrisy we have had to put up with in this House from members of the Australian Labor Party. I want to stress this again so the Minister will understand our objections to the way in which the art in working life program has been distorted. I refer to the way in which artists have been told in official publications that they-

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—It is all very well for the Minister to say `nonsense!'; I will produce the document for him. I produced it last year in the Senate. He took no notice of it then; he tried to pretend that it did not exist. We have here clear evidence of artists being told that art is not to be there for art's sake and artists are not to be funded to bring art into the working place but are to be funded to make the arts another arm of the unions' campaigns. The use of the arts in that way was justified in the art in working life document. I believe that is a disgrace. Senator Short is quite right to point out the special need for this Government to show incredible restraint and caution-certainly for more than it has shown so far-in making clear that there is no capacity for it to be attacked for its vested interest, that there is no capacity for it to be criticised for paying off dissident groups. It has failed to show that care. It has encouraged attack on that ground by being blatant in its support for the enormous amounts of funding under policies set by this Government. It is all very well to say that some of the funding is at arm's length. That is bunkum.

SPEECH.PARA: By setting the policy framework, this Government has encouraged the diversion of millions of dollars away from traditional arts. Many of those traditional arts organisations, by the way, were involved in bringing art into the working place and into the community and included organisations such as the arts councils, which were involved in bringing arts into the country areas. Much of this money has been diverted now to organisations such as the Victorian Trades Hall Council. What an objective view of the arts would come from the Victorian Trades Hall Council! All we have to point out is that a large volume of those grants has come since the research director of the Victorian Trades Hall Council became a member of the board involved in distributing the grants. If the Minister is interested in knowing the name, it is Ms Caswell. I find it offensive for this Minister to get up here and say that art is not simply the right of the rich. If one goes along to the artistic performances-ballet, theatre-in Sydney one will not find that it is only the toffee noses, the rich, who attend them. One will also not find that their funding is proceeding in any way for a polemical attack on the labour movement. In fact, the great bulk of the operas, for example, that one might go to see involve the triumph of the oppressed over the oppressor, particularly, I might say, in an economic sense. It strikes me as extraordinary that, because this Minister is prepared to criticise, to reject the great bulk of Australian artistic endeavour as funded by the Government as being pro the establishment--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not.

—If the Minister is not, why on earth does he make the objection? If he is not, how can he logically object to the impartial funding of the arts and say that this partial, discriminatory funding which he is in favour of is needed because the rest of the arts funding is, in fact, going towards only the toffee noses, the rich? The Minister should look in Hansard at what he said before he interjects. This Government is discriminating in favour of a particular group in the community, is claiming that it is discriminated against and is, in fact, financing the presentation of the arts with a polemic. It is financing in a discriminatory way only those people who are prepared to use their artistic talents to convey a message which happens to suit the trade union movement, because it is being funded through the trade union movement. I believe that is unfair, improper and discriminatory. I believe the Minister's position is intolerable. If the Minister could tell me when he last-as he says he is an artistic person-went to an artistic performance which had a pro-capitalist message or a pro-Liberal Party message--
—The last one that he paid for.

—And he paid for his own ticket, a nice point-a theatrical or any artistic performance which involved the presentation of an anti-labour position in a strong way which was funded by his Government, I would be very interested to see it. But I can tell the Minister that there is a mass of stuff around the place funded by his Government which has been deliberately funded only because it has an anti-capitalist, anti-anyone who is on the right wing, certainly anti-Liberal and anti-National Party bias. I point out to the Minister another bit of funding under this Department: the extraordinary funding of a woman from the South Coast Labour Council. As an employee of the South Coast Labour Council she was financed into song writing. I will bleep the offensive words. She was funded by this Government to write such songs as `Up the President's bleep' which was a description of President Reagan's polyp operation, and it did not refer to his nose. Another song for which she was funded under this Government was a song about pushing bleep uphill. It was an attack on Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-funded by this Government. To get arts funding under this Government it helps if one is an anti-Liberal, anti-coalition--
—It doesn't help; it is essential.

—It is essential, as Senator Short says. But if one goes along to a trade union, gets the trade union to support one and guarantees to submerge one's personality to what the trade union wants and write stuff which is down the polemical track that the trade union requires, one's prospects of getting a grant from this Government's activities soar beyond recognition. It is hypocrisy and nonsensical for the Minister to come in here and say that we are opposed to the art in working life program when he does not know its genesis; he does not know how it was funded. We object not to the program but to the way in which it has been hijacked by the Government to buy off its dissident mates.
