TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add a few words to what I said earlier, as I cannot let the comments made by the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) go unanswered. Most of them follow what Senator Michael Baume has said. We are making a point about putting the trade union movement into a position of privilege, and the Government into a position of great conflict of interest. SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister will know, a recent survey showed that around one million union members in Australia vote for parties other than the ALP, and yet those one million workers are being forced, through the methods that the Government is adopting, to fund a political party for which they do not vote. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some comments about a matter in which the chamber has taken a great deal of interest for some time, and specifically again last Friday following the tabling of the Menzies report on the Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract. I want specifically to address the nature of the very grave problem which has been revealed by that report from Mr Menzies, and which clearly existed. I wish to raise it at this stage because I want to have some better assurances that the problems have been addressed and rectified in the course of the consideration of these Estimates than I have so far received.

SPEECH.PARA: The Menzies report identified what Senator Gareth Evans, at an earlier stage of this debate, called `a systems failure'. That was a euphemistic way of describing what was an almighty bungle. It was not only one bungle but a series of bungles-I suppose that is why the word `systems' is used-which occurred in the Department of Transport (DOT). What bothers me is not that it was an almighty bungle, or series of bungles, in the Department of Transport, or bungles in the Department of Aviation at the time or in the Australian Government Solicitor's office in relation to the deficient advice that it gave, but that the whole show commenced with a bungle by a standing interdepartmental committee (IDC) dealing with the coastwatch program. One of the first findings of Mr Menzies was that there was a delay in other organs of government in reaching a decision to let a further contract for coastal surveillance. This immediately resulted in the period available for processing tenders being unduly compressed, and this process had to be carried out in too short a time.

Therefore, at the beginning of the operation, before one can start to blame the Department of Transport and the others for the way in which they assessed the tenders, there was a serious failure by no less than a standing interdepart- mental committee dealing with the coastwatch program. That meant, as I said, that the tender process had to be unduly compressed. No doubt that is one reason it was not carried out properly. It is about time that the Commonwealth Public Service caught up with the rest of the country and did not have a great shut-down over Christmas and the New Year and, in fact, well into January-an excuse which Mr Menzies prof- ferred for this further compression of time. That is a factor in this day and age which also should be addressed seriously by the Commonwealth Public Service.

The IDC should have been well aware that, as I understand it, the Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd contract for coastal surveillance expired on 31 March this year. The tender process should have been put in train well before that. As it turned out, the contract of Skywest, the former operator, was extended in the first place to 30 June, which gave a little more time. But even that had to be negotiated to cope with the problem. When the contract was finally let to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd-on 12 March this year, I think it was- the Skywest contract, if it had not been for the extension to 30 June, would have expired. Even so, the contract that was let with the new tenderer, Amann, on 12 March this year did not provide for performance until 12 September. The Government let a contract on 12 March knowing full well that the extended arrangements with Skywest would expire on 30 June and that the new contractor was not sown up. This has been the case with the Government all through. There was no legal obligation on the new contractor for performance until 12 September-2 1/2 months after the expiration of the extended Skywest contract.

It seems extraordinary that the Government and the people involved allowed that to happen. When this potential further bungle was discovered, the Government again was able to make arrangements with Skywest to continue the operation until it thought performance would occur in September. As a result of the Government terminating that contract, further arrangements were made for Skywest to carry on the contract. All this has happened as a result of nothing else but good luck and preparedness by Skywest to carry on this vital surveillance which could have been totally terminated by Skywest on 30 June if it had stuck to its rights. The Government would have had no way of providing-perhaps this is even the case now-for the coastwatch of the whole of the northern approaches of Australia over that period of 2 1/2 months.

I say that only by way of introduction to what I want to say. As I said, I want to refer to the enormity of the failure of the system as identified by Mr Menzies. In going through his report, I have identified no fewer than 12 different bungles by one department or another or by senior people, in many cases senior management, in one or other of the departments. Firstly, I have already mentioned the delay in deciding to let the contract. Secondly, Mr Menzies identified that the request for tender document was deficient. He explained why, but I do not have the time now to develop that. Thirdly, Mr Menzies identified the failure of the Tender Assessment Committee (TAC) to carry out what he said was required-namely, a particularly rigorous examination of Mr Amann's capacities and circumstances. I understand, that the TAC was chaired by a senior officer of the then Department of Transport.

We all know now of Mr Amann's deficiencies in terms of his tender, situation and so on, and that is why Mr Menzies said that there should have been a particularly rigorous examination of his capacities and circumstances. The person who was given that task, the Director of the Supply and Services Section of the Department of Transport, was found by Mr Menzies to lack that expertise. For reasons that Senator Evans has already mentioned in the debate, I do not want to rake over the position in which that person finds himself now. It is not the Opposition's intention to do so and it never has been. But we simply have to record the finding that he lacked the necessary expertise, because that is absolutely vital to the debate and our consideration of this matter. What is even worse-I note that this is the fifth failure-is that senior management of the then Department of Transport was aware of this Director's limitations, yet it allowed him to carry out that examination in these particularly difficult circumstances.

Sixthly, Mr Menzies has identified that the Tender Assessment Committee took the wrong approach to the assessment of tender for services. In his report he quoted at some length from the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual to show how wrong the TAC was. He also quoted at length from the transcript of his examination of the Chairman of that Committee to show that the Committee simply took the wrong approach. It took an approach which may have been satisfactory for the supply of goods but certainly not for services.

Seventhly, Mr Menzies noted that, again, the senior management of DOT did not exercise sufficient supervision. There is no mention of who the senior management was. I wonder, in view of what Senator Evans said the other day about counselling certain people, whether counselling extends to the senior management of the then Department of Transport. I ask Senator Evans what he proposes to do about this lamentable performance, twice identified by Mr Menzies, by the senior management of the Department. Eighthly, Mr Menzies identified confusion between the then Department of Transport and the then Department of Aviation as to the role of the latter in the tender process. I would like to say something more about that, perhaps later. But a very important failure occurred.

Ninthly, Mr Menzies identified that some of the advice from the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) was deficient. I do not know whether the AGS can be blamed for that, but certainly senior people involved in some of the process should be seriously blamed for not having ensured that proper staging of start-up dates was included as a term of the contract. Tenthly, Mr Menzies identified that all those concerned with this matter treated far more lightly than was justified the request by Mr Amann or his company for a change of aircraft. It is clear from the documents, when one examines them, that this was not examined at all; it was just assumed that it was okay. It certainly was not okay, despite Senator Evans's talk of trade-offs of one sort or another. That is another matter which should be examined further in this chamber or by the Standing Committee on Infrastructure.

The eleventh system failure identified by Mr Menzies was that the Cabinet submission should have been presented, and the approval for the money should have been obtained from Cabinet under the finance regulations, before the tenders were ever called. Who on earth was responsible for such a major failure-a failure to obtain the necessary Cabinet approval for the expenditure of this large sum of money? The figure was largely unknown before the tenders were called, but it was roughly $20m. Who was responsible for that?

The twelfth system failure, as identified in the Menzies report, is that at the end of this process it was suddenly realised that it was necessary to have a Cabinet submission. The documents had gone through the tender process, the Tender Assessment Committee, the Tender and Contract Board and all the rest of it; those responsible had chosen Mr Amann for all the wrong reasons, as has now become apparent, and the Cabinet submission had to be rushed through at the last minute, with all its deficiencies, flawed as we all now know it to be. The poor helpless Ministers, we now hear, could not even ask a question to find out anything about it. Of course, the Ministers in this Government do not ask questions; they have to be spoon fed.

This flawed Cabinet submission was presented not just at the wrong time-at the end instead of at the beginning-but was rushed through because apparently nobody realised until that stage that it was needed. Who made the decision to present it at that stage because of the rush? No less a person than the Deputy Secretary of the Department. So here we have the systems failure starting with the standing IDC-the non-decision of a standing IDC-and finishing with a decision of the Deputy Secretary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon will appreciate that the Department of Transport and Communications does not have the primary policy responsibility for this program-only the administrative responsibility, which has been the subject of Senator Durack's speech, on which there is much that I could say, but I think it has already largely been said in the course of the debate we had on this matter last week. TALK.START.PARA: —That is particularly vulnerable to prediction.

—That is on the assumption that there are people deliberately seeking to come in under cover of darkness or something. If, as has been rather more often the case in the past, they are just boatloads of people drifting fairly aimlessly in a general compass direction but without any great sense of strategic purpose as to where they are at any given time, clearly that is not so. They ought to be the subject of constant scrutiny, particularly when large sums of public money are involved; and the present circumstances of the need to recommit the Amann tender, if I might so describe it, has given us a slight breathing space in which to reconsider the best way forward in this respect, and we will look at it accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of comments and ask a question in relation to the tender procedures for the coastwatch contract. I think that the report that was presented to Parliament the other day, which has already been the subject of a great deal of discussion and which I shall not pursue in any great detail today, although I am sure it will continue to be pursued in the period ahead, is the most indicting report that I have ever read in terms of bungles in public administration. I shall not go into a lot of detail, other than to say that I do not accept the proposition that it is purely an administrative bungle.

SPEECH.PARA: The report makes it clear that the material that went forward to the Government on which it based its decision was patently inadequate; and any Minister worth his position as a Minister of the Crown should have realised that as that material came to him. There is no way in which ministerial responsibility can be absolved in this present matter, but that is for another day.

The point I raise relates to the departmental arrangements for these tender procedures. The departmental relationships in the Coastwatch arrangements are set out on pages 16 and 17 of the report, which lists the various committees that were responsible for providing advice and analysis of the tenders. There were the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Coastal Surveillance-and the report lists all the departments represented on that Committee-the Operations and Programs Committee; the Tender Assessment Committee; the departmental working party; and the Tender and Contract Board.

I find it absolutely incredible that on none of those committees did the Department of Administrative Services have any involvement; yet that Department is responsible for the preparation of the Commonwealth purchasing manual, of which most of the people involved in this dreadful exercise seemed not even to be aware: not only that, but that Department has responsibility in the broad, as I understand it, for purchasing policy. So I find it almost unbelievable that the Department was apparently not represented in any shape or form in this whole exercise. That is picked up at page 67 of the report, where it states:

Source of advice, other than paid consultants, which appears not to have been considered in the coastwatch matter, is the advice available from major purchasing agencies like DAS and the Department of Defence. Indeed, in addition to its purchasing policy co-ordination role, the Purchasing and Sales Division of DAS has a charter to perform the following services on behalf of other Departments and Authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add a few further remarks to those that I have already made in this debate and perhaps ask another one or two further questions that so far have been unanswered by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans). I concluded my previous remarks by identifying from the Menzies Review of Tender Procedures for the coastwatch Contract the 12 failures that had emerged in this so-called systems failure, which is the nice euphemism that Senator Evans coined earlier on to describe what Senator Short also said, when he agreed with me, is an almighty bungle and which he, who has probably a greater knowledge of the workings of the Public Service than anybody else in this chamber, said is the worst that he has ever heard of in the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that Senator Evans has determined not to look at or face up to is that it was not a bungle that occurred in one place in one section of a department or by any one person. It was, as he so presciently described it, a systems failure. It was not only a system in the Department of Transport but a system in a lot of departments, including an interdepartmental committee and going up to virtually the highest levels in one or other of these departments.

I shall complete my remarks on this exercise by referring to the sort of advice that was apparently given to the then Minister responsible for aviation, the Minister for Resources, Peter Morris, when the whole matter blew up in the Government's face shortly after the contract was let. The contract was let on 13 March and within a few days, although these problems did not seem to be known to the Government at that stage-nothing seemed to be known to the Government during the period in which it was evaluating the tenders-they were widely known in the industry. I asked a question of Senator Gietzelt in this chamber on 18 March, but I might as well have saved my breath for all the sense I received from him about this matter at any stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were a running dog for Skywest then, weren't you?

—Yes, a few choice accusations were thrown around as well. On 18 March Mr Peter Morris, the then Minister for Transport-I believe he was also Minister for Aviation at the time, although the Press statement is under the heading `Minister for Transport'-issued a Press statement to try to cope with this flood of concern and accusation that was already surfacing quite extensively around the nation. Mr Morris said:

SPEECH.PARA: Allegations of impropriety levelled by Skywest Airlines against the Federal Government for the approval of a $17.6 million tender for a 3 year northern littoral aerial surveillance contract to Amann Aviation were unfounded Peter Morris, Federal Minister for Transport said today.

I point out that the allegations of impropriety were levelled by Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd. When I asked Senator Gietzelt my question on that same day, I had not been approached by Skywest. I had become aware of a number of allegations that were being made and of great concerns that were held by people. I recall one of the first bodies expressing concern about it was the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, so it was not only Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd, but that was the story that the Government tried to put out from the beginning. It was just sour grapes by Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd, according to the Government, and, as Senator Boswell interjected, we were accused of being running dogs for Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd. Let us hear what the Minister further said:
The allegations impugn the objectivity and professional judgment of a properly constituted public tender process . . .
Of course, that is not what Mr Menzies has found in his report; in fact, the contrary is true. The Minister further stated:

The tender process which is set down in strict government guidelines has been adhered to scrupulously and all tenders were evaluated by a specially constituted Tender Assessment Committee possessing all the necessary expertise.

I compare the Menzies report recommendations with that statement. It turns out that the Chairman of the Committee did not even know about, or understand, the Commonwealth purchasing manual, and he approached his task completely the wrong way round. Mr Morris said:
. . . a specially constituted Tender Assessment Committee possessing all the necessary expertise.

That Committee was satisfied that the successful tenderer had sound financial backing, fully understood the requirements of the contract on offer, had made realistic provision for costs, and that it had the necessary arrangements in hand to enable an early start up.
We know that the company failed to have an adequate start-up even after six months. Mr Morris continued:

The Tender Assessment Committee was however, satisfied that Amann had realistic and achievable plans to set up its operation in a reasonable time frame. I am informed that the aircraft to be imported is already being fitted out and that delivery is expected . . .

Honourable members should recall that the aircraft was changed after that. According to Mr Morris, the aircraft had already been fitted out by 18 March, even though the aircraft was subsequently changed. He continued:
. . . and that delivery is expected to commence in the very near future.

I wonder what Mr Morris thinks is the `near future', let alone the `very near future'. We know that is what he thought on 18 March and we know that six months later-I do not know whether that is the `future'-the company still had not satisfied the contractual requirements. Finally, Mr Morris exhibited his own ignorance of the Commonwealth's purchasing manual, because he ends up saying:
To reject the lowest acceptable tender . . . would not only be a rejection of the proper processes . . .

Mr Menzies said that to accept the lowest tender, without full and rigorous examination, is in fact contrary to the proper processes, but Mr Morris said that that `would not only be a rejection of the proper processes, but would cost the taxpayer dearly'. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard that 18 March Press statement by Mr Morris.

The document read as follows-
CANBERRA...18 March 1987
COASTAL SURVEILLANCE CONTRACT AWARDED

Allegations of impropriety levelled by Skywest Airlines against the Federal Government for the approval of a $17.6 million tender for a 3 year northern littoral aerial surveillance contract to Amann Aviation were unfounded Peter Morris, Federal Minister for Transport said today.
`The allegations impugn the objectivity and professional judgement of a properly constituted public tender process and do Skywest no credit whatsoever.

`Even if Amann had not been recommended, Skywest were ranked third by cost and still not have won the contract. `The tender process which is set down in strict Government guidelines has been adhered to scrupulously and all tenders were evaluated by a specially constituted Tender Assessment Committee possessing all the necessary expertise.

`That Committee was satisfied that the successful tenderer had sound financial backing, fully understood the requirements of the contract on offer, had made realistic provision for costs, and that it had the necessary arrangements in hand to enable an early start up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans keeps assuring us that all is well now and that nothing like this will happen again, not only in the Department of Transport and Communications but also in any other department of the Commonwealth. We got this guarantee from Senator Evans last Friday. Senator Evans said that, because everybody had been counselled and because of Menzies report, this would never happen again. After this debacle occurred I was interested to ask some questions at the Senate Estimates committee hearings on 19 October into the Department of Transport and Communications. SPEECH.PARA: Although I exonerate Senator Evans from any attempt to stop me asking questions, his own answers were so voluminous that nobody else got a look in-he did not have anyone from his Department answering questions. That was the reason why I have had to get some subsequent answers-alleged answers-to some of my questions.

A matter which always greatly interested me and which certainly staggered Mr Menzies as well was that there was no contractual staging of the obligations to take up parts of this very complicated contract for surveillance extending right around the north of Australia from Broome to Cairns. Clearly, this could not all start up on one day. Indeed, this question was addressed even in the original tender document by Mr Amann, who, when he specified a six-month period for the commencement of operations from all bases, said that there was scope for negotiation of earlier commencement dates. That was in the tender offer itself. I asked why a proposed timetable for the commencement of the operation set out in Mr Amann's letter to the Department of 12 January was not firmly accepted by the Department. SPEECH.PARA: Complete answers . . . are not able to be provided due to the unavailability through serious illness of the senior contract officer involved in the tender assessment and contract preparation work.

It is not completely evident from the material on file why these matters were not followed up in the way that they manifestly should have been. The reason for that is not able to be elicited in the circumstances I have described here by that reference a moment ago and last week. So it is not a matter of trying to conceal anything or trying to perpetuate any administrative failings in this respect; it is simply an inability to give more information than that which has been provided.

Could I just add one word in relation to Senator Durack's opening remarks about my colleague Mr Morris. His statement of 18 March should, of course, be seen in context, and the context was clearly enough disclosed by the opening line of that statement when he said that there is no substance to any allegations of impropriety in relation to the tender process. The whole thrust and flavour of that particular Press release is devoted to contesting allegations which were circulating at that stage, and subsequently, of impropriety. There has been no subsequent substantiation of any such suggestion and it is clearly not being pursued by the Opposition now because the Menzies report and others earlier have clearly intimated that there is just no question of any impropriety so far as the Department is concerned. Failure of administration, yes; impropriety, no.

I think what Mr Morris is referring to is his confidence, essentially, in the arm's length tender process which was in operation. If there is anything that Ministers will perhaps now be a little bit more alert to, it is the traditional reluctance that Ministers have had to involve themselves in the details of tender processes because of the danger of that being seen as untoward ministerial interference in what should be an absolutely objective administrative process? There was certainly a lot of consciousness about that on the part of all the Ministers concerned, thus the emphasis in Mr Morris's Press release about the separateness and the qualifications and so on of the Tender and Contract Board. In retrospect, of course, it appears that his confidence in the expertise and experience of the Tender Assessment Committee was misplaced. I do not blame him, and the Menzies report certainly does not blame him, because he had no material before him on which he could have made any other judgment.

On the documentation that was available, certainly on 18 March when that statement was issued, it is perfectly understandable that he should have expressed the confidence that he did, not only in the lack of impropriety but also in the necessary expertise being vested in the committee and the necessary processes having been followed. I was getting assurances of that kind myself as recently as July and August this year in circumstances which, by then, had given rise to much more legitimate grounds for concern than those that were legitimate for Mr Morris to have had as early as a week after the contract was originally awarded. Remember that this statement was made on 18 March; that meeting with the regional officer of the Department of Aviation, which jangled a few alarm bells, was not had until three days after that. So all this attempt to make much of the terms of that particular Press release is, I think, an unwarranted assault on the integrity, competence and everything else of my colleague and I am sure that Senator Durack in fairness will acknowledge that and not pursue that particular point.

They have bought computers which they cannot use. They have no subscriber trunk dialling available. There are up to 12 people on a party line. I do not know whether everything else exaggerates in the telling on quite that scale or whether it is just a congenital disposition of Senator Boswell to stretch a yarn a point or two.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it was inevitable that Senator Messner would join the ranks of the floggers of dead and wounded horses in this matter. It is a pity that he wants to occupy the very scarce time of this chamber on matters that can obviously be pursued through the Senate committee to which this matter has been referred. Nevertheless, I will endeavour to answer him as best I can. The finding on this matter of the Menzies inquiry is best summarised on page 74:

SPEECH.PARA: Amann's inquiry on 19 February 1987 whether he could use a different type of aircraft for the service was treated more lightly than it should have been. He should not have been informed orally that he could, subject only to the requirement that the aircraft met performance specifications. Such a proposal required full financial investigation.

That is not disputed; but it is disputed and will continue to be disputed that the change of aircraft, albeit insufficiently examined, in itself could have given grounds for the termination of the contract. To think so is to miss the point about the nature of this contract. It was not for the supply of particular, specified goods; it was for the supply of particular, specified services-services pursuant to a standard of performance that was set out in the tender document. Provided that the aircraft met those performance standards, there was no ground for thinking that the change of aircraft would in itself change the basic ground rules of the contract and thus provide a basis for termination. That is what I have said consistently on this matter. That is the truth of the matter and I am sure that is how it would have appeared had any Minister at the time given attention to this matter.

I am not briefed as to what transpired between the Minister and the Department or the Minister's office and the Department, except that my brief is quite silent on the matter. I believe all relevant documentation has been tabled. There has been no attempt to conceal anything of this kind in that documentation. If Senator Messner has not been able to turn up anything in it, he is welcome to pursue the matter further in the Committee, as no doubt he will be inclined to do. I am not in a position to give an absolutely confident statement about this because I am not fully briefed, but for what it is worth my understanding is that there were only questions asked from time to time by the Minister's office on the progress of the contract, and the issue was not squarely brought to the attention of the Minister-certainly not brought to his attention in a way that would have raised questions about the credibility of the whole likelihood of the contract being performed. So that is really what it boils down to. I have no reason whatsoever to suppose, on the basis of the briefing and the documentation and everything else that I have seen, that there was any particular ministerial involvement in this matter.

The more important point I make is that, even if the Minister had been aware of the change in aircraft, that in itself would not have given him grounds to act. To the extent that there was a failure to follow through the financial implications and to test in detail the question of whether the trade-off to which I previously referred between maintenance reliability and higher fuel costs and so on really involved net gains or losses, that question should have been followed up; but, to the extent that it was not and that there was not a full financial examination of the implications of that, that was merely a compounding of earlier errors in the process rather than some brand new and exciting error being added to the list.

If the people administering this tender approached it wrongly with the view that all they had to be satisfied about was that the price was lower than anybody else's price and that the performance criteria were satisfied on the face of the material before them, they also should have acknowledged a responsibility to thoroughly evaluate the likelihood of the whole performance of the contract being followed through. If they did not do that properly in relation to the earlier stage of the contract, it can hardly come as a surprise that they did not do it when the question of variation arose.

TALK.START.PARA: —At one stage before dinner we were discussing the Estimates Committee Hansard of 19 October 1987 in which the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) indicated that the former Minister for Aviation, Mr Morris, had in his mind some information as to the state of play concerning the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd contract and the likely inability of Mr Amann to complete the contract. This is an important point to note because up until now we have not had any indication that information concerning the state of play as to whether Mr Amann had the ability to continue or complete the contract had been communicated to the Minister's office. In fact, we had been led to understand that the Minister was completely in the dark in regard to the situation concerning Mr Amann's contract and, consequently, was not able to exercise any decision-making capacity in respect of the termination of the contract or otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: Having noted that, I would like to draw the Committee's attention to the situation that I think reveals itself in the course of events over the couple of months surrounding the time at which the contract was first granted to Mr Amann. Firstly, the contract was granted on 12 March 1987. Around about 21 March an interview with Mr Amann was conducted by the New South Wales Regional Inspector of the then Department of Aviation into Mr Amann's ability to continue and complete the contract. Many matters came to light as a result of that interview that displayed a very great lack on the part of Amann Aviation to be able to complete the coastwatch contract. About a month after that, on 23 April as far as we know, Amann Aviation advised the then Department of Aviation that it intended to change the type of aircraft that it would use for surveillance purposes. We know that in the original tender documentation the aircraft specified was a piston-driven aircraft. The new type of aircraft which Mr Amann advised the Department that he would utilise thereafter was a turbine-driven aircraft. It is well known that these two types of aircraft have different levels of performance and, consequently, the second type of aircraft may not have been able to perform the same functions as the first. Some time elapsed while the Department apparently gave consideration to whether or not the second type of aircraft would be adequate for the surveillance contract.

As I understand it, from information that the Minister tabled in the Senate at an earlier time, there is a record of a conversation between a Mr Reece, who is Minister Morris's senior private secretary, and a Mr Richardson in the Department, concerning a letter that Amann received from the Department of Aviation which ended:
Mr Reece asked me to express the Minister's grave concern-
I repeat `grave concern'-
at Amann's ability to fulfil his contractual obligations and the danger of a subjective view being taken of the ability to carry out the task.

That occurred on 21 May 1987, about one month following the time when application was made by Mr Amann for the change of aircraft. The point I wish to draw to the Committee's attention is that obviously there was communication between the Minister's office and the Department, and Minister Evans did admit that before dinner.

The second point that ought to be made is that, that communication having occurred, the indication was that Minister Morris at that time was expressing grave concerns as to the future of the contract. We already know, by way of evidence given to the Estimates Committee by Minister Evans, that, indeed, there were matters of concern about the contract in the mind of the then Minister for Aviation. We can only assume that that started some time before 21 May 1987. Yet, we find that the Department was quite happy to go along with the arrangement that the new aircraft be allowed to be operated by Amann.

The point I am making here is a simple one: Minister Morris, having been aware of the difficulties of the contract-the aircraft change was discussed within the Department and apparently approved between 23 April and 21 May-had an opportunity to stop the contract at that point by refusing the change of aircraft to be undertaken by Amann. The point is quite simple: the Minister had the power at that point to refuse the carrying on of the contract from that point. The question that has to be asked is: Why was not action taken at that time to stop the contract by refusing to allow the change of aircraft? It is in this respect that Minister Evans's defence on that issue falls to the ground. If we accept the point that that request could have been refused at that time, the defence of Minister Evans, who has apparently relied on the point that no action could have been taken until 12 September 1987 when the contract apparently expired, falls to the ground.

I believe that the Minister has to satisfy the Senate and the people of Australia, and certainly the Liberal and National parties, that Minister Morris did not know of any of these matters and that he did not convey to the Department his grave concern about the future of the contract. If he did have that grave concern, why did he not take immediate action to stop the progress of the contract at that vital moment?

That concern, I think, probably waxed and waned over that period.

There was certainly a very considerable amount of genuine confidence within the Department itself, as I understand it, that, notwithstanding the various difficulties that kept being encountered, the ultimate start-up date would be met. No doubt some of that infectious enthusiasm also carried itself from time to time into the Minister's office and perhaps into some of the answers that were given in the chamber. There is no doubt that concern was expressed and it does no service to Senator Messner's political cause to wave triumphantly the minute of 21 May that I tabled in this place. There is a reference there to Mr Reece, Mr Morris's secretary, asking Mr Richardson to express the Minister's grave concern at Amann's ability to fulfil its contractual obligations. Of course there was concern. The question is: What could the Minister do by way of translating that concern into termination of the contract?

TALK.START.PARA: —Couldn't he have refused?

—The short point is that he could not do anything. It is the judgment that he made at the time on advice. It is the judgment I made. I had concerns of my own when I came into this job on 24 July and was briefed about it a couple of weeks later as to where it was at. I had concerns. I looked at the possibility of terminating the contract against the history of the performance up until then and I made exactly the same judgment as he made, that it was not an essential term of the contract--
—This was before the change of aircraft was agreed to by the Department.

—Senator Messner has utterly failed to understand what this particular contract was all about. This contract was about the supply of services. It was merely incidental to the essential terms of that contract how those services would be delivered. Provided the aircraft in question were capable of performing the particular requirements that were set out in the contract, it did not matter-in terms of the strict letter, the strict terms, the essential terms, the fundamental terms, if you like, of the contract, a breach of which would entitle one to terminate the contract-which aircraft were flown, whether it was Tiger Moths or the Concorde. It did not matter, provided the operator could satisfy the performance criteria. Obviously only a limited range of aircraft manifestly were capable of performing, but clearly the turboprops that were finally chosen and the original piston-engine aircraft were each equally capable of performing the task.

SPEECH.PARA: We have acknowledged that there should have been greater investigation as to the financial implications, but prima facie there was no reason why anyone would have supposed that that would make the contract non-performable in the terms in which it was originally entered into. There was an interjection earlier from another quarter of the Opposition which suggested that there was no contract at all at that stage. Of course, there is no formalised contract entered into to fully embody and lay out in systematic form all the particular terms that have been agreed to at various stages along the way. But there was, of course, an enforceable contract that was entered into once one had the basic elements of the offer, the acceptance, the consideration and so on involved in the submission of the tender and the Commonwealth's acceptance of that.

Nobody has ever doubted but that there was a contract. A lot of people have taken the view-I have certainly shared it myself-that that should have been translated into a formal, clean contractual document embodying all the subsequent variations as to the particular clauses and so on that occurred along the way. But there was a contract. It was a contract which the Commonwealth was bound by. It was a contract which could not be terminated unilaterally by the Commonwealth, except at the risk of paying very considerable damages, unless the contract was breached. The difficulty about the way in which the contract had evolved was that no particular firm test of breach was available up until 12 September, or very close to it, when it became apparent, I suppose a few days before 12 September, that it was wholly unlikely that the strict letter of the contract was going to be carried through; and notice was accordingly given of the Commonwealth's intention to terminate there and then on 12 September unless it was observed. But one could not make that judgment right back at the end of March; one could not make that judgment in April; and one could not make that judgment in May. The pre-conditions were simply not there.

It is a total misunderstanding of the position in which the Commonwealth found itself, with the particular terms of the contract that it had before it, to think that, with all the concern in the world, that concern could have been translated into action to terminate the contract. That is the truth of the matter. What I have said has been absolutely consistent in this place, publicly and in every other way since the very first day that this matter got into the public domain or that it involved me. Really I just cannot understand-unless Senator Messner has just completely misapprehended the basic points in issue here-as to why he should be going off with such confidence down a totally blind alley.

There are more and more South African apartheid protests.

There was a New South Wales dispute, as I mentioned earlier, relating to proposed changes in workers compensation. Twenty-eight ship days were lost in Sydney in April on that score. Disputes in April delayed ships in Sydney and Port Kembla. These were disputes which had nothing to do with the shippers and were basically secondary boycotts. There was a protest against Press statements about the operation of a coal loader in Port Kembla. That lost two days export time at a time when we are desperate to maintain our reliability as an exporter of coal. This dispute involved a Korean ship. TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it would be possible to respond to the request to extract the number of disputes which are attributable to political factors and do not immediately impinge upon the economic interests of the two parties concerned, and to attribute the number of days lost because of strikes so characterised. SPEECH.PARA: Costs to the shipowner are reasonably easily attributable because, unless the ship is on its last legs with everybody already paid off, every extra day in port obviously will have implications for the use of that vessel elsewhere. A relatively easy attribution can be made in that case. But what about the costs to the exporter, importer or port operator? They are enormously variable, depending on the circumstances of the case. To pull out those circumstances would involve much more data than the Department can be expected to keep. In the case of the exporter, for example, whether he loses ultimately, by virtue of the delay, in terms of the deliverability of the goods, would depend, among other things, on the perishability of the cargo. In the case of the importer whether, by virtue of any delay that occurs at the other end, he is left lamenting at the end of the day would depend on such things as the inventory condition of that importer. For the port operator, it would depend to some extent on whether other ships which are due in are being kept out as a result of the continuation of the industrial action. And so on.
