The style of the programming on that channel of the ABC seems to have changed a great deal over the last several years and, I have to say, by no means for the better. The prevailing and overwhelming impression that any consistent listener to Radio National must have is that there is too much talk. Whereas one could once find some good music-at least three times out of four-during the day, it now seems as if discussions, commentaries and the like predominate. Obviously, that would not matter if the quality of the talk were up to it, but the truth of the matter is that the quality of the talk is not up to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting it is not up to Senate standard?
—There simply is not enough high quality talk available to be up to Senator Evans's standards. So inevitably much of it is repetitious and, I might add, second rate.
—Just like here.

—Just like Senator McKiernan's interjection-second rate. Even when that channel turns to music, it seems to be uncertain as to what is required. Jazz, modern music and classical music are provided in a higgledy-piggledy fashion. Surely listeners would prefer clearer separation of the types of music to be obtained on that channel when musical programs are being performed. Does anyone in the ABC ever monitor audience reaction to the programs provided? If they do-as I was assured they do by a very high source in the ABC this afternoon-do they ever take any notice of the results? As well as finding an answer to the question that I have just posed on the composition of the ABC's musical programs, the ABC might learn whether anyone listens to The Coming Out Show, for example.
—Indeed they do.

—Senator Giles's tastes may be so perverted as to remain glued to the ABC when The Coming Out Show is on. I am glad to have her declare her allegiances to that program. I can assure Senator Giles that the program does not command mass appreciation from the Australian people. For the last decade The Coming Out Show has been working and re-working topics that delight radical feminists, such as Greenham Common-Greenham Common, for God's sake!-and nuclear disarmament, which is another matter on which Australia has not the slightest impact. The views of Australians have no influence whatsoever on the whole future of nuclear disarmament, notwithstanding the presence, or the occasional presence, in this chamber of two senators elected on that premise. They do not happen to be here at the moment.
—Not too often.

—I agree entirely with Senator Knowles; they are not here too often. They are normally flying around the country at taxpayers' expense to lecture on the subject. Affirmative action is another topic which has been done to death-reiterated and reiterated-on that program. Incest is another. Our ears have been assailed month in and month out by programs about incest. I am prepared to agree that, obviously, incest is an ugly practice and is to be wholly frowned upon in our society. But to listen to that program one would think that the Australian family was made up of nothing but incestuous relations.
—Yes, you would not be very mistaken.

—Senator Giles interjects to say that one would not be very mistaken if one thought that the Australian family was mainly taken up with incestuous relations. Is that what the honourable senator really believes the Australian family is all about? By her interjection she has entirely disqualified herself from commenting any further in the debate.
—The incidence is a great deal higher than any of us ever expected.

—That was not the point I made. Either Senator Giles was not listening or she is given to making intemperate interjections. I suggest that either she withdraw from the debate or listen more carefully in future. Another favourite topic of The Coming Out Show is child abuse. Again, child abuse is a totally discreditable, totally anti-social, totally malevolent practice. But does anyone really believe that the Australian family experience is made up of, to pick up Senator Giles's proposition, incest and child abuse? If one listens to The Coming Out Show one would think that Australian family life was composed of nothing else. Women's shelters is another favourite topic of that program. I think that Senator Giles ought to be in a women's shelter, but that is by the way. No, I withdraw that remark. I will not pursue the point because I do not wish to level any personal comments in the honourable senator's direction. I have the highest regard for her. I simply draw the Minister's attention to the fact that this program goes on about issues which, while individually extremely important and significant in themselves, are totally distorted, totally drawn out of all reference to reality, by this program on the ABC week in and week out, month in month out and year in and year out for the past decade. And it is still going on. Abortion is another favourite topic.
—If you were a regular listener you would have a great deal more variety--

—Senator Giles is interjecting on the subject of abortion. Apparently, she also believes-I look to her to disavow the proposition if she wishes to do so-that the program's views on abortions are wholly admirable and desirable. The point I am trying to make over the inchoate interjections of the rabid senators opposite me is that this program has nothing to do with Australia, the Australian community and the generality of the great majority of Australians-the decent people who make up our community. It is no good Senator Giles sitting there and sniggering because she has had the bad judgment, as well as the bad taste, to interject these kinds of remarks into the debate. The program is totally unrepresentative of anything that purports to be representative of Australian life. Only Senator Giles and some of her colleagues opposite would attest otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to another of ABC Radio National's pet programs-First Edition-a program which puts itself forward as a book reviewing program. If one depended on First Edition for one's knowledge of the books that were to be reviewed in our community, one would imagine that nothing was ever written on subjects other than women's issues, the environment and the peace movement. Those are the only things the program ever talks about. The Coming Out Show and First Edition, while gems of their kind, are only, so to speak, a little more extreme than the ABC's current affairs programs generally. Generally, the ABC's current affairs programs lack balance. They fail to set up true debates between equal opponents. Either they do not set up debates at all-they simply allow opinionated people, usually of the Australian Labor Party persuasion, to put forward their views-or, if they do purport to strike a balance, they usually do so by setting up some very competent spokesman for the Government. I am perfectly prepared to concede to Senator Evans that there are competent spokesmen for the Labor Party, and I am sure he would like to put himself forward in such a capacity. They match him or her against some dud purporting to be a spokesman for the Opposition. It takes me back to the early days of the Fraser Government when usually they had Mr Whitlam or some other spokesperson for the then Opposition and they would put Billy McMahon up against him, for God's sake, so that they had two speakers against Mr Fraser! Really, that is the kind of thing that the ABC calls balance.

An example of the kind of thing I am talking about is the weekly discussion, the little Mutt and Jeff show on the ABC program PM, between the compere or producer of that program, Mr Paul Murphy, on the one hand, and Mr Ken Randall, on the other hand. These two go at it hammer and tong for five or seven minutes in the latter part of that program each Friday night, and naturally they agree with each other tremendously. They do nothing else but agree with each other. It would be hard to find two more like-minded people. That is what the ABC no doubt calls balance.

On another aspect of that general topic, I refer to interviewers not merely on radio but also on television. In some cases on ABC television it is most glaringly obvious that interviewers simply fail to ask crucial questions of their interviewees-unless they happen to be members of the Opposition. I am entirely in favour of all politicians being asked hard questions, tough questions, by interviewers; and I have been subjected to a fair few of them in the past few months, and quite rightly so. I make no complaint about that, but I do point out, however, the total absence of such hard questions being addressed to this country's Treasurer (Mr Keating) or its Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who is usually handed the most patsy questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not in the country to be asked them.

—No, he is not here most of the time, as Senator MacGibbon reminds me, and he is about to go off on another overseas trip at the end of this week. But when he is here and when he actually appears on television he is never asked a question that would cause him any embarrassment in responding. All politicians should be quizzed hard and pressed really hard-with appropriate courtesy, of course, and that is something that ABC interviewers interviewing people of a different political persuasion generally fail to provide. Of course, trade union leaders are almost never quizzed. I am sure you would agree with that, Mr Temporary Chairman. Instead, interviewers usually fall over themselves to be gentle and polite to the Simon Creans of this world or to Bill Kelty when he occasionally appears on a program. Almost never do they put to these same leaders the public point of view, the kinds of questions that the ordinary fellow in the street wants asked.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a fascinating speech from Senator Stone. It seemed to be a bid for recognition of a new, rounded John Stone-not just a one dimensional economic man but an absolutely all-round troglodyte, on the basis of the evidence of that speech. The nub of his attack concerned, of course, Radio National. His first grievance was that there was too much talk. Too much talk, he said; not enough music-profoundly oblivious to the creation, since he was a lad, of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's FM channel which, of course, exists for the sole purpose of broadcasting to the nation at large good music of a kind that one assumes Senator Stone would appreciate. We have a much wider diversity of programming and a much higher proportion of talk to music on mainstream Radio National as a result of that.
—My point was that there wasn't too much good talk.

—Then we have the second grievance-not enough good talk; too much Coming Out; too much about nuclear disarmament; too much about incest; too much about child abuse; too much about abortion. All I can say to Senator Stone is that he had better be careful because, on the evidence of the recent Townsville meeting of the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia, the Party is leaving him behind.

SPEECH.PARA: His final cry from the heart was that there is too much matching of first-rate, competent spokesmen from the Government against dummies of one kind or another from the Opposition. I could not believe my ears, but that is what Senator Stone said. The only chapter and verse he offered by way of confirmation of that was the relatively ancient example now, although a compelling one, I acknowledge, of Billy McMahon being matched up in opposition against Gough Whitlam in government. But obviously Senator Stone has a very deep and compelling sense of grievance about the current state of affairs whenever he hears Bob Hawke being matched against John Howard, or Paul Keating being followed by Andrew Peacock. All I can say to Senator Stone is, `John, I know how you feel. I appreciate the deep sense of wounding that that must give you and I know what leads you to say these things'.

All I want to say is that, extraordinary speech though it may have been, it is one that I do not think is fantastically appropriate to burden the chamber with at this time of night, not least given that we are so far behind with the Estimates because, of course, we have no particular capacity to determine-nor should we have as a Government or as a Parliament-the content of the programming of the national broadcaster. We can fund it and perhaps set priorities for funding. Perhaps that is something that we should consider in the period ahead in broad program categories, in terms of broad objectives; but the notion of being able to pick and choose between what we as a Government or a Parliament should allow to be broadcast in terms of our peculiar definition of what may or may not be good talk or what may or may not be an appropriate balance between talk and music seems to me to be fairly extraordinary; and, as a result, I hope we can press on with other items.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel compelled to start my brief remarks with four confessions to Senator Stone. The first is that I happen to be an Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) enthusiast, and perhaps that reflects my second confession, that I am in fact interested in the peace movement, as presumably are those who voted for the Australian Democrats and the Nuclear Disarmament Party. I am also a conservationist and I have some interest in women's matters. So some of us out there do in fact support the ABC. However, I really wish to make criticism and I was hoping to pose a question to the Minister who has now left the chamber, but presumably someone will report my criticisms and questions to him.
—He is sitting on the back bench.

—I am sorry; I understand the Minister is on the back bench. That is fine. I would like to make my comments quite specific, unlike Senator Stone who seemed to wander over the whole course of the ABC's adequacies, or inadequacies in his views. I would like to make my comments quite specific to the publication of one book and the advertising of that publication which has presumably involved the expenditure of several hundred thousand dollars. The book I am citing is Ashes of Vietnam-Australian Voices published by William Heinemann Australia in association with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Honourable senators may have seen the advertisement on ABC television in recent days encouraging Australians to buy and read this outstanding piece of military history and social commentary. It is true that I have received widespread reaction from members of the Vietnam veterans community, many of whom are deeply offended by this document and puzzled by the fact that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation would have been involved in its production, publication and now advertising in appealing to Australians to purchase and read it. They are teased also by the fact that the publication of this book and its promotion coincided, sadly, with the welcome home marches.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge honourable senators to address themselves seriously to this contradiction. In support of my argument I shall cite passages from the book. I have read the book and I have seen the advertisements, as other senators have. The publication Ashes of Vietnam-Australian Voices was the subject of a Mike Willesee segment in which he brought together the author of the book, Stuart Rintoul, and the national President of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, Tim McCombe, in debate. Subsequently the book has been reviewed by Colonel Rick Haines, who is a military historian, who for 20 years was a regular army officer, who retired with the rank of lieutenant-colonel after completing two tours of duty in Vietnam and who has visited the country on several occasions since. I emphasise the fact that this publication has evoked much negative reaction from Vietnam veterans. I pose the question: What brought the ABC to publish and now advertise such a document, and at what financial cost? Colonel Haines begins his review of Ashes of Vietnam-Australian Voices by stating:

Ashes of Vietnam is neither a good piece of military or social history nor is it a good piece of journalism. It lacks academic objectivity and contains no obvious evidence of any effort on the author's part to obtain corroborative evidence for the statements recorded by him. It is little more than a one-sided, sensational piece of reporting dressed up to look like good journalism.
He then cites some of the mechanisms to dress up this document:

The book has all the imprimaturs of good journalism, such as the ABC logo on the front cover and acknowledgments to all the right organisations including the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia and the Australian War Memorial. These tend to give the book an appearance not justified by the contents. Unfortunately, some readers may accept the contents as being a factual account of what the Vietnam experience was for the nearly 50,000 Australians who served there; but it isn't.
It is not a factual account of the experience of many of the 50,000 Australians at all. The review continues:

This book contains excerpts from some 105 interviews which Rintoul selected from `over 100'-to quote from the dust jacket. In most cases, the first excerpt from each interview is accompanied by a few lines from the author to provide a little background to the interviewees. The excerpts or statements, are preceded by a preface in which Rintoul summarises the Vietnam experience for Australians.
I now refer to some of the phrases used to summarise the Vietnam experience:
In this preface, he makes such statements as:
`The lives of many Vietnam Veterans are characterised by violence, alcoholism, divorce, self destruction'.
`There was bitterness first for the way they came home.'
`Instead they found themselves the untouchables.'

`Australians in Vietnam were guilty of acts of barbarity. There were Australians whose morality was so eroded that they murdered villagers, raped women, tortured and killed wounded enemy soldiers and mutilated corpses. But they were not like that before they went to Vietnam.'

There are many such examples in the review. I have received strong negative reaction from veterans who say that there are no substantiated cases of this type on record, and if there had been, Australian governments of the past 20 years would have been obliged to take action under the War Crimes Act. No such action has been pursued. In fact, these statements that are published under the auspices of the ABC are unsubstantiated. In fact, I believe they are possibly libellous. This document of unsubstantiated supposed evidence was being promoted at taxpayers' expense precisely at a time when the Government was encouraging and financially supporting the welcome home marches.

The timing was bad. The decision to conjointly publish this book was bad. The advertising of it at present is tasteless. I call upon the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) to justify those actions on behalf of the ABC and to answer the many Vietnam veterans who are grossly offended by its publication and by its promotion. I turn to the final pages of this rather long review by Colonel Haines in which he states:

There are Vietnam veterans and their families who have suffered from the problems detailed in the last chapter in this book, and they deserve all the support and help they can be given. To be fair to Rintoul, perhaps he was trying to help them by explaining what Vietnam meant to these men and women. If this was the case, he has failed because of the distorted conclusions he has reached in the preface to this book.

Some of these conclusions are almost insulting to the majority who served in Vietnam with honour, returned home without problems, and have carried on to make a significant contribution to Australian society since then. Many of these are in veterans organizations such as the RSL, the Korea and South East Asia Forces Association, the VVAA or the AATTV Association; actively helping those of their comrades who have suffered because of Vietnam. Some will feel that the allegations will not help those veterans for whom they have cared and worked so hard; others will feel that the allegations may reflect unfairly on them.

It is unfortunate that just as many Vietnam veterans finally `came home' last month in Sydney, this book was published. Some of the allegations it contains made it impossible for some veterans (including some of Rintoul's interviewees) to really come home 15 or 20 years ago. I hope that none once again begin the `long retreat' talked about by Rintoul because of this piece of poor journalism.
I call upon the Minister to justify this publication under the logo of the ABC and to inform honourable senators how much was spent on the publication and how much is being spent on its promotion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) is an autonomous organisation, and long may it remain so. I am happy to supply information about the cost of the publication but I am not going to stand in judgment on publishing decisions of the kind that obviously have been made in this instance. I must confess that I find it extraordinary that an Australian Democrat, passionate as allegedly the rest of his Party are, concerning values of free speech and non-censorship and letting it all hang out in a variety of ways, should get up and mount an attack on some publication, urging that it should never have been published.
—I'm putting the other side of the argument; that's all I'm doing.

—The honourable senator can put the other side of the argument to his heart's content, but if he knew anything about the responsibility and the relationship of the Government and the ABC, and anything about what these Estimates discussions are supposed to be about, he would not be wasting the time of honourable senators with a little bit of breast beating of a kind that may go down well with particular constituencies whose support he is obviously trying to attract. It has nothing whatsoever to do with anything this chamber is presently embarked upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator McLean and the thrust of his argument. I regret that the intelligence of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) is such that he cannot follow what the honourable senator is saying. Senator McLean made a point that illustrated what Senator Stone was talking about earlier. It is not a matter of freedom of speech and freedom of expression. The question Senator McLean is asking, and Senator Stone is asking, is why taxpayers' funds are being expended on a perverted lifestyle in the form of things like The Coming Out Show and those other programs?

SPEECH.PARA: Why is history being bowdlerised the way it is in this regard? Freedom of speech is one thing, but the use of taxpayers' funds for dishonest programs is another. The great cross that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has to bear is that current affairs programs have not been in the hands of the far left, they have been in the hands of communist sympathisers for decades. I have had enough of it. I have had enough of paying taxes to support those people. If they want to prosecute that point of view, let them go out and raise their own funds; do not let them ask me to tax the Australian community to put a one-eyed, perverted view of what the Australian community is about. I support to the hilt what Senator McLean said.

I have several questions for the Minister in the field of aviation. Firstly, how many apprentices is the Department of Transport and Communications training this year, and has there been any significant change in its apprentice intake from previous years? In a different area, in relation to the firefighting services. I understand that some years ago there was a dispute between the Australian Federal Police and the rescue and firefighting services regarding who is in control of emergency procedures if an accident or emergency occurs at an airport. Was this dispute resolved and who officially is in control? Secondly, do these two services, the Federal Police and the rescue and firefighting service, exercise together? Are there any full-scale emergency exercises in which these two services are involved? Is there any requirement for these exercises to be carried out? How long is it since the last exercise was carried out?

In a different field again, in relation to the duty free concessions at airports, I have been advised that the Minister has ordered an inquiry into the granting of an extension by three years of the five-year contract for the present concessionaire at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Is that true and, if so, why was the inquiry mounted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the questions about apprentices and firefighting, I do not think I am in a position to give the honourable senator any answer. I will have to take those questions on notice and respond as soon as I can. As to the question about the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport concession, the situation is that I have asked a senior member of the Department, Mr Rainbird the Deputy Secretary of the Department, to review the circumstances of the departmental decision that was made to extend the tender by a period of three years from, I think, October or November next year. On the face of it there would not appear to be anything other than a sound commercial justification for the decision, that being in essence that very substantial disruption was caused to the business of the present duty free occupant, Allders International Pty Ltd, which not only involved it in potential claim of compensation against the Commonwealth for loss of business and so on associated with that disruption during the present period but also involved it, from another perspective, in very substantial fit-out costs of some $3 1/2m to re-establish itself in the new location within the present terminal complex-an expenditure which would manifestly not be able to be amortised over the remaining very short period of the present five-year contract which expires in the latter part of next year.

SPEECH.PARA: It was in those circumstances and against that background that the decision was made at a departmental level, with, I think, the Minister simply being notified after the event. It is on that basis that the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) I think said when this matter was raised in the other place that he believed that there was no ground for query. However, since the question has been the subject of some assault from various quarters and some suggestions that, come what may, there should have been a tendering process-I do not think that those claims have been made with a full appreciation of what was involved in the disruption over the present period-and because there are some questions which have arisen about the proper construction of the statute and so on as it affects this kind of circumstance, I did ask for a review to take place; not a boots and bells and whistles sort of a review, just a review of the circumstances of it in order that I could be fully apprised and make my own judgment as to whether any more substantial action subsequently needed to be taken. The results of that have not yet come to hand. I expect that within a few days. We will look at it and make a judgment accordingly. I do not think that I had better comment on the first part of Senator MacGibbon's speech or we will be here all night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak on this part of the Appropriation Bills but I am afraid that onhearing what Senator Stone had to say, I felt that I must at least say a few words in defence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and some of its programs.
—Don't start them, please.

—I will be very brief. Programs such as The Coming Out Show do deal with subjects that perhaps are not dealt with in other programs. That is no reason why they should not be dealt with in that particular program. I suggest that Senator Stone, who is not here at the moment, is most fortunate indeed if he has no personal connection with issues such as, child abuse, incest or the terrible sadness and loss associated with abortion. However, having 10 days or so ago launched for the Australian Capital Territory its new emergency telephone service for domestic violence I was quite horrified at that launching at the figures that are available in regard to domestic violence right here in Canberra. There is a need for this service and the refuges which are set up in Canberra. I would argue very much against what Senator Stone had to say on these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Just briefly on one other matter, Senator Stone mentioned at the start of his speech that people who are occupied at home and able to listen to the radio do enjoy the radio. Therefore, I would have thought that the delightful mix that the ABC gives us in the music line, of jazz, classical music and light modern music, would be enjoyed by all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do intend to speak very briefly on the matter addressed by Senator Jenkins. The Coming Out Show has been going for as long as I can remember-for 10, 12 or probably more years. I know that when the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) came to Hobart a number of representations against this program were made. I made one representation against it, as did Senator Wriedt at that time. He thought it was a dreadful program. That is what Senator Stone was saying. I agree very much with what Senator Jenkins was saying; however, that is not what Senator Stone was referring to. I do not know whether Senator Jenkins has ever listened to The Coming Out Show. It is a dreadful show; absolutely appalling. It does not represent Australian women at all, not in any way. The only consolation that I have is that it has such a very small listening audience. This is what the Tribunal pointed out to us. It consoled both Senator Wriedt and me that the listening audience was so minuscule that really there was not much to worry about. I think that the people who listen to that program are to a large extent destroyed already. It could not destroy them any further.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I will not move on to the main thing about which I want to speak in the Committee tonight. Can the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) tell me whether the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal had any view or has done any investigation on back masking.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —As to Senator Walters's worries, all I can say is that I will look into them and see what information I can find out to either substantiate or countermand the particular worries that she has.

—They are not my particular worries. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was sent a tape quite some time ago with allegations of back masking. Could the Minister let me know what inquiries the Tribunal has already made regarding the tape it has been sent? Would he let me know whether he feels there is any justification in the allegations?

—Lots of people send the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) tapes about all sorts of things and seek its intervention. I do not know what position the ABT has reached in relation to this matter, but I will certainly ask it, I will certainly find out and I will certainly let the honourable senator know.
—When?
—As soon as I possibly can, but I do not think it will be tonight.
—Before Christmas?
—I am certain we can manage that before Christmas unless it is a very subtle plot. Of course, then it might take longer to unravel.

—During the last election campaign there was a great deal of criticism of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) for its political bias. In fact, it was estimated that in Tasmania some 90 per cent of the callers accused the ABC of bias in favour of the Australian Labor Party. I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table: Will there be a better monitoring of bias during future election campaigns, or will this Government use the ABC as a propaganda machine in the next election at the expense of the taxpayer?

—Some might say that sounds a pretty good idea, but it is not an idea that I would begin to countenance, Senator. I do not accept the allegation that has been made about bias during the conduct of the last campaign.
—Could 90 per cent of the community be wrong?

—Anything is possible, Senator Walters. I know there is a continuing discussion about the proper mechanism for resolving complaints of this kind that go to programming, content and so on. That is a particular matter which was the subject of some assurances in this chamber in the context of the broadcasting debate. It is something in which I am taking an interest. We will see what can be done about it! I suspect that one difficulty is that when people make complaints about these matters there is a concern that the appearances of their resolution may not be fully satisfactory. It may well be, at least for some sorts of complaints, that if we had some greater degree of externality or independence there would be greater confidence in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's undoubted propriety in these matters. This raises difficult and sensitive questions which I will need to discuss with the ABC, as I am proposing to do. Beyond that, I have no further comment.

—Accusations of bias were made in respect of the claim that the Australian Labor Party was running a low key campaign and that it had decided to run on its record. There was also criticism in respect of the reporting of the policies put up by the Opposition. These matters were raised at the Estimates Committee hearings. Does the Minister agree with what has happened, or does he agree that something should be done so that at the next election or at future elections-whether they be State or Federal elections-the ABC will not be allowed to give an inference of bias?

—I do not know about the honourable senator's capacity to stop people creating an inference of bias in the mind of mindless and prejudiced rednecked sorts of observers, but my judgment is that it is a very difficult thing to stop. I do not think I would be capable of achieving that even if I wanted to, which I do not.

—Would the Minister consider it an inference of bias for a rather prominent Australian Broadcasting Corporation commentator, when commenting on the election results as they came out, to say, `Oh we are not doing too well in this area', when the Australian Labor Party was not doing too well? I thought that might be considered even by the Minister to be a slight inference of bias towards the Labor Party.

—Just as I might get up now and say, `Well, we made a rather silly contribution to the debate then, didn't we', so, too, it would be perfectly possible as a grammatical expression for a commentator describing a situation in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to be quite misunderstood in the way in which he was expressing a quite objective state of mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, for making yet another plea for support for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), but I could not let Senator Stone's remarks pass without some comment. It surprises me that when certain subjects, such as peace, women's issues, the environment and nuclear energy are mentioned, Senator Stone becomes almost apoplectic. He really goes off the deep end quite remarkably. The claim that the ABC is, in any sense, a left wing body or displays left wing bias is rather surprising when one looks at the totality of broadcasting in the media in Australia. We must recognise that the media-with the exception of the ABC-is entirely in private hands and exhibits enormous right wing bias. One sees very little serious comment on public affairs which holds a mirror up to society on any of the commercial media or in any of the newspapers.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the funding of the ABC, I point out that this country spends many billions of dollars on its media. Funding for the commercial media is raised by way of what is, essentially, a private tax. The profits which go into advertising pay for that media. Let us not forget that that money is entirely controlled by the owners and, therefore, there is nothing wrong at all with the ABC supplying a form of media for those groups in society which are not catered for by the commercial media at all.

It seems to me that there are a number of excellent programs on the ABC. If it were not for the ABC we would not get these programs in this country at all. If Senator Stone were still in the chamber, I would raise the issue of Aboriginal deaths in custody and this issue of police corruption in his own State of Queensland which were initially raised on the Four Corners program. I think it behoves this Government and every other government to continue to support the work of the ABC more extensively because if it were not for the ABC many voices would not be heard in this country at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —To say that the privately owned media are biased towards the conservative aspect is absolutely incredible. According to Bob Hawke, Packer, Bond and Murdoch are his mates.
—Don't be jealous.

—I am not jealous; I am just stating facts. Consequently, the bias is definitely towards the mates. It is ridiculous for Senator Coulter to try to say that the bias of private ownership is towards the conservative parties. It is absolute rubbish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since we are dealing with communications, I would like to take the Minister to the closure of station VNG, with its accurate time signals. VNG was the only station in Australia broadcasting accurate time signals-accurate to within one or two milliseconds, which was enormously useful for astronomers and seismologists and people involved in research where an accurate time signal was available. As I understand it, the Minister at the time asked the then Department of Resources and Energy to find out whether the station, which had started in 1964, should be kept in operation. The Department went to the Bureau of Mineral Resources. The Bureau of Mineral Resources, which was one of the major users of station VNG, did not consult fully with the Department. My advice is that the seismologists and the research staff who used the signal when it was available are incensed that it has now been cut.

SPEECH.PARA: The impression in the scientific community in Australia is that the decision was based on totally inadequate research as to how much the station was used. There are a significant number of research institutions at remote sites in Australia where it is quite impossible financially to provide some caesium clocks or atomic clocks to give the timing accuracy needed for the sort of research work that is done. The existence of station VNG, which had been running since 1964, was extremely useful-in fact essential-for the work. My advice is that Telecom Australia claimed that it cost $100,000 a year to maintain the station. I think the transmitting site that it operated from had gradually run down and VNG was the sole operator at Lyndhurst when transmission ceased.

On all the evidence I can find, there seems to be a very pressing case from the scientific community to have an accurate timing base available to it. The cancellation of this station has left it very much in the air. The scientific community is also very upset because, while it knew that the Minister was looking at whether the station should be kept any longer, apparently no advice was given to it. All it knew was that the station stopped transmitting either at the end of September or in the early part of October. I ask the Minister whether he is satisfied that, whoever the Minister was at the time, the best advice was tendered to the Government. Whatever happened, will the Government replace this signal or timing system in any way at all?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was a matter in which I took an interest as Minister for Resources and Energy in seeking from the then Minister for Communications a guarantee that the station would be kept open. I then inherited the problem as Minister for Transport and Communications and proceeded to close the station, which was regarded by some as a rather churlish thing to do. But it was on the basis of good advice, or at least advice that I found persuasive at the time in terms of the availability of alternative methods and the timeframe within which people had been notified, I was told, and had been given an opportunity to make a plausible case against it. As a result, alternative arrangements were unable to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just been handed a bit of paper which was Telecom's announcement in September. Of course, the point is that Telecom no longer used the service as its own needs for time and frequency signals are met through its own terrestrial network. The reason for the closing down of the service is that the Lyndhurst property was expected to be offered for disposal early next year. But the key bit in Telecom's statement is this:

Before deciding to terminate the VNG service, Telecom approached known major users of the service offering to transfer free of charge the existing transmitting equipment. Discussions and consultations over the past 12 months, however, were not successful in identifying another organisation-
including my own; as it then was, the Bureau of Mineral Resources-
prepared to take over responsibility for the VNG service.

I think that probably needs some further supplementation because, as I recall it, there was a rather more substantial brief on the various issues that were involved and the alternative ways in which the time signal could be received by those organisations and enterprises that were dependent upon it. I will seek that information and make it available to Senator MacGibbon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister what can be done about the problem of reconnecting telephones that have gone out of order recently during the heavy rain in Sydney.
—Ha, ha!

—It is all very well for the Minister to laugh, but when Telecom cannot fix the phones of young people who go to work during the day before they go to work or when they come back from work, this Government is not giving any service to the people of the community through Telecom, its instrumentality. It is all very well for the Minister to laugh. I have not asked too many questions of him tonight, so he should be pretty thankful about that. These people who go to work should be entitled to have their phones fixed before they go to work or when they come back at night. Quite often, new installations are carried out at weekends when people get plenty of overtime and it suits them pretty well to do it. But when a private phone goes out of order, it is not always fixed at a time that is helpful to the people who have the problem. I think the Government should do something about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask about a matter that came out at the Estimates-the operator assisted service, the 011 service, and the fact that delays have now increased and the number of calls has decreased. That is also something that the Minister can laugh about, because that service-the 011 service-is not helping the people who are using it! Getting back to the installation problem, in reply to a question on notice about the average time for installations we are told that the flat rate charges for miscellaneous installation and removal work were $123 for business and $103 for residential. The answer states:
At this stage the charges for customers under the new system are, on average, about 20 per cent less than the old flat rate and these savings are similar in both urban and country locations.

I ask the Minister: How could the savings be the same when people have to travel 40 miles in the country to fix a phone whereas in the city they do not have to travel very far at all? How can the time charges be the same?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A series of questions was asked about particular operational matters involving Telecom Australia which seem to me to be a bit difficult to deal with in the context of an Estimates debate in the Committee of the Whole. It would be very much desired if phones that are out of order could be connected before or after work. I appreciate the inconvenience that is generated for consumers when their needs cannot be attended to at times when they are at home. It is a problem of sequencing generally in the provision of services. It is very difficult for any service organisation to so arrange its affairs as to be able to meet consumer needs to that extent, but obviously it is the kind of improvement in service that one would be hoping Telecom would be able to achieve in the period ahead as greater emphasis comes on alternative ways of communicating and a more competitive environment emerges in which Telecom will probably have to lift its game.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to 011 operator assisted calls, obviously there has been a deliberate policy decision to try to press consumers of telephone services into using direct dial techniques for both interstate and overseas calls. The technology and the ease of access into the system when doing it that way are such that that is an entirely sensible state of affairs. It is obviously much cheaper and in many ways more flexible and convenient for people to do it that way; but old habits die hard. It becomes a matter, I suppose, of building in some disincentive for people using operator-assisted calls. Staff numbers have been allowed to wind down very significantly in that area in the hope and expectation that only in exceptional circumstances in the future will people use operator-assisted calls and they will use the direct-dial mechanisms. As to the last point raised about the time components in service call charges, I am not in a position to give any response at this stage. I will take that question on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an advantage in speaking on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) because, although I note that Mr Hill was unable to attend the Senate Estimates committee hearings, he was able to attend this morning at the Joint Committee of Public Accounts public hearings. They were of some interest and are worthy of hearing about in this debate. One of the things dealt with in the hearing this morning was the problems that the ABC has had on a continuing basis with inadequate accounting. The Auditor-General's report has drawn attention to this matter, as was pointed out in the estimates hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hill was able to shed some light on problems encountered in this period. They are fourfold. Firstly, he said that he had inherited a mammoth organisational change which, had he come to his position before he did, he would not have embarked upon. But he decided it was a wiser course of action to accept the breakup of the organisation into five separate operating entities and to proceed from there. He felt that to undertake further organisational changes would only have exacerbated the situation. It was interesting to hear that he personally would not have embarked on that change.

Secondly, Mr Hill said that the changeover to accrual accounting had been a very large task to take on at the same time as this mammoth organisational change was taking place. Thirdly, he pointed out that it was very difficult in the ABC to deal with the management question. As the ABC is a creative body and, of necessity, attracts creative people, over the course of years the habits had developed whereby promotion into managerial positions had come from within the creative ranks. He pointed out that it is necessary so that people who are skilled in creative areas make good managers. He said specifically that he felt management within the ABC structure left something to be desired.

Fourthly, Mr Hill pointed out that some 50 per cent of the people who work in the financial and computer areas are casual or consultant based and perhaps they are looking forward to having more permanent staff come in to take over this important area of getting the accounts in order. The Auditor-General had pointed out that there have been some serious breaches of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act. From asking questions about how the ABC had breached the Act, we found it was largely in two areas. The first was in the old system of accounting. Where expenditure would have exceeded a specific allocation for a particular project ministerial authority had to be sought. On several occasions this ministerial authority had not been sought and the expenditure thus had been unauthorised.

The second and quite interesting area of the breach was where the ABC had incurred expenditure on behalf of a third party in an unauthorised manner. This third party turned out to be none other than the Parliament House Construction Authority. Costs in the range of $43m had been incurred by the ABC on behalf of the Parliament House Construction Authority, subsequently to be reimbursed. A further problem that was identified, and it is interesting to look at it in the context of this debate, concerned property of the ABC which is linked to board members and senior members of staff, for them to take home and use. This property seems to be in the nature of radios and televisions so the people may be able to look at or hear programs. Some $760,000-worth of equipment can presently be identified in this area. One of the criticisms in the Auditor-General's report was that there had been no proper inventory of this material. This is now being attended to.

It was encouraging to hear that the ABC is now able to identify ABC shops as profit centres. Although there has been no costing, for instance, of the free television advertising that is available to the ABC to advertise those shops-no account has been taken of that-the ABC still chooses to identify the shops as profit centres. The concerns that came out of the hearings this morning were largely that although there seems to be a distinct effort on the part of management to come to grips with the problems of poor accounting and accountability in the ABC, it seems to be taking an inordinate amount of time to achieve a noticeable improvement. Many of the questions asked related to why the process cannot be speeded up and why the ABC cannot be brought better into line.

I draw the chamber's attention to these matters because it is quite significant that the judgment would be that during the years since the ABC was changed from a commission to a corporation, far too much has been attempted at a time and, accordingly, the results have been less than satisfactory. The amount of work required to make the ABC an efficient body is something which management is quite concerned about but clearly is not yet on top of. Let us look at the options the ABC is now facing and the cuts of say $20m that it is facing immediately. The options it has to look at came out, as well, in the hearings this morning. I asked the question: With regard to national news and current affairs programs, particularly taking into consideration what is happening in New South Wales with the changes of personnel in a current affairs program, was it the intention of the ABC to have a more national face and look at phasing out State news and current affairs programs? Mr Hill answered that that was not a decision which had been made but it was unreasonable to think that the ABC, as a national broadcasting body, should not have national news or national current affairs programs. However, he recognised the constituency that it served, which had a particular concern for regional-based news and current affairs. He did state that should cut backs in funding for the ABC continue, that option would have to be put to the board for consideration.

Furthermore, Mr Hill says that the only areas in the ABC that are left to cut, having thinned all the services that have been maintained, will be its representation in various parts of Australia. The importance of bringing this part of the information to the Senate's attention is that the ABC will have to make some tough decisions and the Government cannot shy away from them. It will finally have to answer for what decisions are made to cut back services or alter the shape of the ABC as it presently is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether a response is required but let me just say this: I am sure that Mr Hill will be indebted to Senator Bishop for the relatively sympathetic way in which she read the minutes of this morning's Public Accounts Committee hearing. I think Mr Hill has had a pretty gruelling sort of day, starting with the Public Accounts Committee, then having lunch with me and then having a session with the National Party of Australia in the afternoon, culminating in Senator Stone's response to the-
—The high point of his day.

—He presumably regarded it as going downhill all the way. To the extent that Senator Bishop is raising questions about the implementation of some of the audit matters that have been raised in the past, let me just say for the record that I report quarterly to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) on progress to fix up these things or prevent them from happening again. All the Auditor-General's references are taken very seriously in this respect. I am confident that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) is in the business of getting its managerial act together. It is a labyrinthine, huge, sprawling organisation that has long needed a pretty rigorous managerial shakeup. I think it is getting that at the moment. How long it takes to get the process completed I do not know.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I would quickly make in respect to this morning's news, which was repeated by Senator Bishop, is that it should not be assumed that there will be cuts of $20m or anything like that to the ABC this year. That is a matter to be resolved in the Budget process. The particular figures that Mr Hill has referred to are just the forward estimates that have been flagged, forward estimates that are prepared on a pretty rigorous and sophisticated basis by the Department of Finance these days and in a way which rigorously excludes and puts in the basket of having to be negotiated or fought for all over again whole categories of expenditure which more reasonable people than Department of Finance officers might think are ongoing forms of expenditure but which, nonetheless, are regarded as ones that have a life when, say, a program of capital works is expended and have to be sought again as new policy. It is against that background that most of these cuts in the forward estimates have occurred. It bears no necessary resemblance to what the final budgetary outcome should be and it is a little early for scare tactics of the kind that some might be minded to implement at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring to the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) the changes that have occurred in respect of the remote commercial television service (RCTS), which I think he commented upon some weeks ago in the Senate. He drew our attention--
—And some hours ago, earlier today, too.
—We are about to get another serve. This service was initiated by the Government back in 1987. It was supposed to be the answer to all--

—I beg your pardon, 1985. It was supposed to be the answer to all the problems of providing television in outback areas. It has all but collapsed under this Government's mismanagement. Not at any stage has there been a clear presentation as to how the RCTS will be put into place. Quite apart from that, we know that individual licensees have surrendered licences or transferred them to other licensees at very low values and consequently the system appears to be on the verge of collapse.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps this is characterised best in an article which appeared in Australian Communications this month uner the heading ``The RCTS mess'. It displays a photograph of the Minister proudly talking to people who are running the Imparja television service in Alice Springs. It makes the point that there has been some change of ownership of the QSTV licensee, who is seeking to move the licence as I understand it, to the Parry Corporation Ltd, which is acquiring the licence to operate the Queensland network known as Q-Net as well. The situation that arises is interesting because it raises the question of how the technology is being fitted together. I noted in this morning's Australian an article which refers to innovation for communications and the ground work for the future. It deals with this particular problem. It states:
Mr Parry is also the new owner of Q-Net the Queensland Government's private network.
The problem with the deal is that the Q-net service is a dedicated 12 watt transponder whereas the RCTS licensees were to sign leases for 30-watt transponders.
This is the technology of the satellite. Therefore, the lower the voltage, the larger the dish needed to receive the signal. The article goes on to state:

If the QSTV proposal goes ahead, households that have already installed small dishes will have no option but to continue using the small dish and put up with poor reception, or buy a larger dish at a cost of $1500 or more.

Mr Chairman, this indicates the problems that are arising with the Government's constant change of policy. Having headed in the one direction of providing a service apparently on a 30-watt transponder off the Aussat satellite, it has now allowed a change to a 12-watt transponder. Any people who have already purchased equipment in order to receive signals off the 30-watt transponders will now be unable to do so with any degree of efficiency and effectiveness. Consequently, they will find that they wasted their money and need to purchase another reception dish to fit the new system that will be provided by Mr Parry under the new arrangements. This brings into very close focus the ill thought out Government policy in this area. It also brings to attention the lack of co-ordination in the Government's broadcasting policy in the last few months.

I will focus now on one of the applicants for a licence for the remote commercial television service-Imparja, the Aboriginal run station operating out of Alice Springs. It is apparently due to commence service on 1 January next year and will serve the Northern Territory, excluding Darwin, and the northern part of South Australia, together with the western part of South Australia. Obviously, those are very remote areas. Questions of viability must be raised about Imparja's ability to broadcast a commercial service through that whole immense but very sparsely populated area. The Government has apparently been in negotiation with the Northern Territory Government to provide a subsidy of $2m to Imparja to undertake the commercial service to be provided through that area. Recently, under pressure from Federal Government cutbacks, the Northern Territory Government reduced its funding for Imparja by $2m. Consequently, no subsidy will be coming from that source.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't anything to do with who got the licence that led to that reduction, was it?

—Senator Evans may be able to inform us to some greater extent about this. The fact is that the service seems to be surrounded by a great deal of uncertainty at present because the funding simply will not be coming from the Northern Territory Government. But, of course, it is an open question as to whether or not the Federal Government will now seek to stand in the place of the Northern Territory Government and provide a suitable subsidy. My question is: Is the Government intending to do that? If it has no intention of replacing the funds that otherwise would have been provided by the Northern Territory Government, what other choices has it contemplated in terms of making sure that a service will be provided in those remote areas of Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: This brings me to the point about what has recently transpired in my own State of South Australia. In a letter from the Minister addressed to the Chairman of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS), dated 7 October, it is made clear that the Minister intends to proceed with the aggregation of licences throughout South Australia and Western Australia. This follows the already passed legislation which provides for the aggregation of television services in the three eastern States. This, of course, runs contrary to the proposals that the Government put down last June when it indicated that there would not necessarily be aggregated television services for South Australia and Western Australia for some years to come. Yet, the Government has now changed its mind and is seeking to press local regional television services in South Australia and Western Australia into an aggregated situation.

I instance the cases of the three regional stations in South Australia, one operating in the Spencer Gulf region, around Port Pirie, Whyalla and Port Augusta, another in the south-east based on Mount Gambier and serving the lower south-eastern districts of the State and the other a small service serving only about 38,000 people in the Riverland district, and based at Loxton. A question arises for those who are inquisitive enough to ask about this. If Imparja Television is going to find it difficult to remain viable, is it the Government's intention to enforce aggregation of the three regional television stations of South Australia with Imparja, or is there some other plan designed to bring about aggregation of those three stations with the three Adelaide based networks? Or is there a combination of those two plans to be implemented, which will bring about aggregation of all three different services into one network, presumably based on Adelaide?

The Minister's letter addressed to FACTS is not clear on this point and does not provide us with any clues as to what the Government's final decision on this matter will be. It is an important matter because it challenges the question of localism in the various regional television services that are currently broadcasting in the Iron Triangle and the Green Triangle in the south-east and the Riverland districts. All people who are connected with those particular television services naturally have a very big interest in what local programs are provided and will be interested to know exactly what the Government's intentions are in this regard.

One other matter that I would like to bring to the attention of the Minister is the question that I raised during the Estimates committees debates in respect of Australia Post and the practice of so-called re-mailing, which is a means by which letters can be directed to another country in bulk and remailed from that point to a second country, using concessional rates of postage available in that second country. Apparently, there are four Australian companies operating this particular kind of service for the benefit of Australians. The question arises as to whether that is legal or not. I am not certain about that, and I would like to hear from the Minister as to whether he considers that it is. From the reply that was provided by Australia Post, I see that some discussion is going on between international postal administrations as to whether or not this activity should be combated. The point is that it raises some doubts as to whether or not there are some ways being sought, and obviously obtained, by private operators in Australia to get around the postal laws that apply in this country.

I would like to know the names of those four companies that were set down in the Minister's reply to my question in the Estimates Committee, as they are not set down in the answer provided to us. The answers are important to know as a matter of public interest, but I would also like to hear from the Minister exactly how he regards this kind of operation, and whether it is legal or otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a mixed bag of lollies for me to finish up-I hope-the Estimates with. To start with the remote commercial television service (RCTS). I do not think that the West Australian Golden West Network Ltd would be terribly impressed to hear Senator Messner's characterisation of the whole RCTS scheme as a mess. As I understand it is operating successfully in that part of the country. the central Australian licensee Imparja Television is off and running, or about to be. It has the wherewithal to get started. The basic problem is revenue flow. In the years ahead, that problem will be redressed, as I understand it, if the Northern Territory Government honours what was generally believed to be the undertaking that it gave. Certainly it generated a reasonable expectation of a flow of funds to the RCTS licensee for central Australia. It is a matter of some regret that there seems to be some reluctance to come through with that. I have certainly been trying to get the Northern Territory Government to honour what people reasonably believe was an undertaking at the time of the licence hearing and I am hopeful, as a result, that the central RCTS proposal will proceed.
—Has it given you a final reply?

—No, as far as I am aware it has not. I cannot recall having seen one, so I am still awaiting it. In terms of the north-east, a transfer of the licence has been accomplished, subject only to Australian Broadcasting Tribunal approval, from the original licensees to the Parry Corporation and ICOM Satellite Services Pty Ltd organisation and I have every ground for confidence that the RCTS concept will proceed there, as I said about 3 1/2 hours ago in answer to a question, when this matter was first raised in the debate. We are turning full circle for the umpteenth time.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that Senator Messner has got himself terribly muddled between his 12-watt and 30-watt transponders and his understanding of the technology involved. My clear understanding is that the RCTS licensee in the north-east is planning to use a 30-watt transponder. Certainly, that is the basis on which the RCTS licence was granted, and obviously there are difficulties if one sticks with the 12-watt transponder. If Senator Messner thinks of a weak beam needing a large dish to pick-up signal, he will realise that for a strong 30-watt beam, one needs only a little dish to pick it up, because it is strong. In the context of the 12-watt transponder, there would obviously be problems of getting people to buy larger dishes than they might have committed themselves to already. The Commonwealth Government would certainly not look to that with any enthusiasm at all.

So far as the south-east is concerned, it is still a matter for resolution as to how the remote areas or those not presently served by licences in the south east will be served. I am hopeful that we can get some sort of solution, although hopefully not one that gives the saturation coverage that was originally proposed. Perhaps the north-east one can be made a bit more viable by extending down into the south-east area, and perhaps, too, the Imparja licence can be made a bit more viable by extending its coverage and revenue return accordingly into the south-east domain.

As to the future of aggregation in South Australia and Western Australia, or other like means of getting extra services to country and regional audiences in those States, those two States were left out of the original aggregation scheme that is now being introduced down the eastern side of Australia. There are no particularly clear cut plans in mind about how to proceed from here. I recently wrote, on 7 October, to the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations asking for a program of consultation in Western Australia and South Australia, with a view to devising some mutually satisfactory means, perhaps in consultation with the metropolitan licensees as well, for getting improved and expanded services. I hope that we can report progress at this stage.
